note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: WHy doe you grieve thus still?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Twold melt a Marble
And tame a savage man, to feele my fortune.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: What fortune? I have liv'd this 30. yeares
And run through all these follies you call fortunes
Yet never fixt on any good, and constant,
But what I made my selfe: why should I grieve then,
And that I may mould any way?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You are wide still.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You love a gentlewoman, a young handsome woman,
I have lov'd a thousand, not so few.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You are dispos'd.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You hope to marry her; 'tis a lawfull calling
And prettily esteem'd of, but take heed then,
Take heed dear brother of a stranger fortune
Then ere you felt yet; fortune my foe is a friend to it.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Tis true I love, dearly, and truly love,
A noble, vertuous, and most beauteous maid,
And am belov'd againe.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: That's too much a conscience
To love all these would run me out ô my wits.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Prethee give eare, I am to marry her

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Dispatch it then, and I'le goe call the Piper.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But ô the wicked Customes of this countrey
The barbarous, most inhumane, damned Custome

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis true, to marry is a custome
In the world; for looke you brother,
Woo'd any man, stand plucking for the Ace of Harts,
With one packe of cards all dayes on's life?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You doe not
Or else you purpose not to understand me

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Proceed, I will give care.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: They have a Custome
In this most beastly countrey, out upon't.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Lets heare it first.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: That when a maid is contracted
And ready for the tye o'th Church, the Governour,
He that commands in chiefe, must have her maiden-head
Or ransome it for mony at his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How might a man atchieve that place? a rare custome?
An admirable rare custome: and none excepted?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: None, none.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: The rarer still: how could I lay about me?
In this rare office? are they born to it, or chosen?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Both equall damnable.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Me thinks both excellent
Would I were the next heire

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: To this mad fortune
Am I now come, my marriage is proclaim'd.
And nothing can redeem me from this mischief,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Shees very young;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And faire I dare proclaime her
Else mine eyes faile,

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Faire as the bud unblasted.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I cannot blame him then if 'twere mine own case.
I would not goe an ace lesse

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Fye Rutillio
Why do you make your brothers misery
Your sport and game?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: There is no pastime like it

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I look'd for your advice, your timely counsell,
How to avoid this blow, not to be mockt at,
And my afflictions jeer'd.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I tell thee Arnoldo,
An thou wert my Father, as thou art but my brother,
My younger brother too, I must be merry
And where there is a wench it can, a young wench,
A handsome wench, and sooner a good turne too,
An I were to be hangd, thus must I handle it.
But you shal see Sir, I can change this habit
To doe you any service; advise what you please,
And see with what devotion I'le attend it?
But yet me thinks, I am taken with this custome.
And could pretend to'th place.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Draw off a little?
Here comes my Mistris and her Father.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: IA dainty wench;
Woo'd might farme his Custome

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: My deare daughter,
Now to bethink your selfe of new advice
Will be too late, later this timelesse sorrow,
No price, nor prayers, can infringe the fate
Your beauty hath cast on you, my best Zenocia,
Be rul'd by me, a Fathers care directs yee,
Looke on the Count, looke cheerfully and sweetly;
What though he have the power to possesse yee,
To plucke your maiden honour, and then slight yee
By custome, unresistable to enjoy you;
Yet my sweet childe, so much your youth and goodness
The beauty of your soule, and Saint-like modesty,
Have wonne upon his wilde minde, so much charm'd
That all power laid aside, what Law allows him,
Or suddain in fires, kindled from those bright eyes,
He sues to be your servant, fairly, nobly
Forever to be tyed your faithfull Husband:
Consider my best childe:

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: I have considered

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The blessednesse that this breeds too, consider
Besides your Fathers Honour, your own peace,
The banishment for ever of this custome
This base and barbarous use, for after once
He has found the happinesse of holy marriage
And what it is to grow up with one beauty,
How he will scorne and kicke at such a heritage
Left him by lust and lewd progenitors.
All Virgins too, shall blesse your name, shall Saint it,
And like so many Pilgrims goe to your shrine,
When time has turn'd your beauty into ashes,
Filld with your pious memory.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Good Father
Hide not that bitter pill, I loth to swallow
In such sweet words:

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The Count's a handsome Gentleman,
And having him, y'are certaine of a fortune,
A high and noble fortune to attend you:
Where if you fling your love upon this stranger
This young Arnoldo, not knowing from what place
Or honourable strain of blood he is sprung, you ventur
All your owne sweets, and my long cares to nothing,
Nor are you certaine of his faith; why may not that
Wander as he does, every where?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: No more Sir;
I must not heare, I dare not heare him wrongd thus,
Vertue is never wounded, but I suffer.
'Tis an ill office in your age, a poore one,
To judge thus weakly: and believe your selfe too,
A weaker to betray your innocent daughter,
To his intemp'rate, rude, and wilde embraces,
She hates as Heaven hates falshood.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: A good wench,
She sticks close to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: His faith uncertaine?
The noblenesse his vertue springs from, doubted?
De'e doubt tis day now? or when your body's perfect,
Your stomacks well dispos'd, your pulses temperate,
De'e doubt you are in health? I tell you Father,
One houre of this mans goodnesse, this mans Noblenesse
Put in the scale, against the Counts whole being,
Forgive his lusts too, which are halfe his life,
He could no more endure to hold weight with him;
Arnoldoes very looks, are faire examples;
His common and indifferent actions,
Rules and strong ties of vertue: he has my first love,
To him in sacred vow I have given this body,
In him my mind inhabits.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Good wench still

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: And till he fling me off, as undeserving
Which I confesse I am, of such a blessing,
But would be loth to finde it so—

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: O never;
Never my happy Mistris, never, never,
When your poor servant lives but in your favour,
One foote it'h grave, the other shall not linger,
What sacrifice of thanks, what age of service,
What danger, of more dreadfull looke then death,
What willing martyrdome to crown me constant
May merit such a goodnesse, such a sweetnesse?
A love so Nobly great, no power can ruine;
Most blessed maid goe on, the gods that gave this,
This pure unspotted love, the child of Heaven,
In their own goodnesse, must preserve and save it
And raise you a reward, beyond our recompēce;

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I aske but you, a pure maid to possesse,
And then they have crownd my wishes: If I fall then
Goe seek some better love, mine will debase you.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: A pretty innocent foole; well Governour,
Though I think well of your custome, & could wish my selfe
For this night in your place, heartily wish it:
Yet if you play not faire play, and above boord too,
I have a foolish gin here, I say no more;
I'le tell you what & if your honours guts are not inchanted

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I should now chide you Sir, for so declining
The goodnesse and the grace you have ever shewed me,
And your own vertue too, in seeking rashly
To violate that love heaven has appointed,
To wrest your daughters thoughts, part that affection
That both our hearts have tyed & seek to give it,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: To a wild fellow, that would weary her;
A Canniball, that feedes on the heads of maides,
Then flings their bones and bodies to the Devil,
Would any man of discretion venture such a gristle,
To the rude clawes of such a Cat-a-mountain?
You had better teare her betweene Oaks, a Town bull
Is a meer Stoick to this fellow, a grave Philosopher,
And a Spanish Jennet, a most vertuous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Does this seem handsome Sir?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Though I confesse
Any man would desire to have her, and by any meanes,
At any rate too, yet that this common hang-man,
That hath whipt off the heads of a 1000. maids already
That he should gleane the harvest, sticks in my stomack:
This rogue that breaks young wenches to the saddle,
And teaches them to stumble ever after;
That he should have her? for my brother now
That is a handsome young fellow; and well thought on,
And will deale tenderly in the businesse;
Or for my selfe that have a reputation,
And have studied the conclusions of these causes
And know the perfect mannage, I'le tel you old Sir,
If I should call you wise Sir, I should bely you,
This thing you study to betray your child to.
This Maiden-monger. When you have done your best
And think you have fixt her in the point of honour
Who do you think you have tyed her too? a Surgeon,
I must confesse an excellent desector,
One that has cut up more young tender Lamb-pies—

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What I speake Gentlemen, was meer compulsion
No Fathers free-will, nor did I touch your person,
With any edge of spight; or straine your loves
With any base, or hired perswasions; Exit.
Witnesse these tears, how well I wisht your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: There's some grace in thee yet, you are determined,
To marry this Count Lady,

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Marry him Rutillio?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Marry him, and lye with him I meane,

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: You cannot meane that,
If you be a true Gentleman, you dare not,
The brother to this man, and one that loves him;
I'le marry the Devill first

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: A better choice
And lay his hornes by a hansomer bedfellow,
A cooler o' my conscience

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Pray let me aske you;
And my deare Mistris, be not angry with me
For what I shall propound, I am confident,
No promise, nor no power, can force your love,
I meane in way of marriage, never stirr you,
Nor to forget my faith, no state can wound you.
But for this custome, which this wretched country
Hath wrought into a law, and must be satisfied;
Where all the pleas of honour, are but laughed at,
And modesty regarded as a may-game,
What shall be here considered? power we have none,
To make resistance, nor policie to crosse it:
'Tis held religion too, to pay this duty.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: I'le dye an Atheist then.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: My noblest Mistris
Not that I with it so, but say it were so,
Say you did render up, part of your honour,
For whilst your will is cleare, all cannot perish;
Say for one night, you entertained this monster
Should I esteeme you worse, forc'd to this render?
Your minde I know is pure, and full as beauteous;
After this short eclipse, you would rise againe
And shaking of that cloud, spred all your lustre

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Who made you witty, to undoe your selfe, Sir?
Or are you loden, with the love I bring you,
And faine would fling that burthen on another?
Am I growne common in your eyes Arnoldo?
Old, or unworthy of your fellowship?
dee thinke because a woman, I must err,
And therefore rather wish that fall before hand
Coloured with custome, not to be resisted?
dee love as painters doe, onely some peices
Some certaine handsome touches of your Mistris,
And let the minde passe by you, unexamined?
Be not abusd; with what the maiden vessell
Is seasond first, you understand the proverbe.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am afraid, this thing will make me vertuous,

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Should you lay by the least part of that love
Y'aue sworne is mine, your youth & faith has given me,
To entertaine another, nay a fairer,
And make the case thus desp'rate, she must dye else;
D'ee thinke I would give way, or count this honest?
Be not deceiv'd, these eyes should never see you more,
This tongue forget to name you, and this heart
Hate you, as if you were borne, my full Antipathie.
Empire and more imperious love, alone
Rule, and admit no rivalls, the purest springs
When they are courted by lascivious land-floods,
Their maiden purenesse, and their coolenesse perish.
And though they purge againe to their first beauty,
The sweetnesse of their taste, is cleane departed.
I must have all or none; and am not worthy
Longer the noble name of wife, Arnoldo,
Then I can bring a whole hart pure & handsom.

sp.speaker: Arnol.
sp.l: I never shall deserve you: not to thanke you;
You are so heavenly good, no man can reach you:
I am sorrie I spake so rashly, t'was but to try you.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You might have tryed a thousnd women so,
And 900, fourscore & 19 should ha' followed your counsell
Take heed o' clapping spurrs to such free cattell,

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: We must bethinke us suddenly and constantly,
And wisely too, we expect no common danger.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Be most assur'd, I'le dye first.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: An't come to that once,
The Devill picke his bones, that dyes a coward
I'le jog along with you, here comes the Stallion
How smug he lookes upon the imagination
Of what he hopes to act? pox on your kidnes,
How they begin to melt? how big he beares
Sure he will leape before us all: what a sweete company
Of rogues and panders, wait upon his lewdnesse?
Plague of your chops, you ha' more handsome bitts,
Then a hundred honester men, and more deserving
How the dogg leeres.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: You need not now be jealous
I speake at distance to your wife, but when the Preist has done
We shall grow nearer, and more familiar.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'le watch you for that tricke, baboone, I'le
Smoke you: the rogue swets, as if he had eaten
Graines, hee broyles, if I doe come to the
Basting of you.

sp.speaker: Arno.
sp.l: Your Lordship.
May happily speake this, to fright a stranger,
But 'tis not in your honour, to performe it;
The custome of this place, if such there be,
At best most damnable, may vrge you to it,
But if you be an honest man you hate it,
How ever I will presently prepare
To make her mine, and most undovbtedlye;
Beleeve you are abus'd, this custome fain'd to,
And what you now pretend, most faire and vertuous.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Goe and beleeve, a good beleife does well Sir;
And you Sir, cleare the place, but leave her here.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Your Lordships pleasure

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: That anon Arnoldo,
This is but talke

sp.speaker: Rut
sp.l: Shall we goe off?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: By any meanes
I know she has pious thoughts enough to guard her:
Besides, here's nothing due to him till the tye be done
Nor dare he offer.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Now doe I long to worry him:
Pray have a care to the main chance. Ex. Arn. and Rut.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Pray Sir feare not

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Now, what say you to me?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Sir it becomes
The modestie, that maides are ever borne with,
To use few words.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Doe you see nothing in me
Nothing to catch your eyes nothing of wonder,
The common mould of men, come short, and want in?
Doe you read no future fortune for your selfe here?
And what a happinesse, it may be to you,
To have him honour you, all women aime at?
To have him love you Lady, that man love you,
The best, and the most beauteous, have run mad for?
Looke and be wise, you have a favour offerd you
I doe not euery day propound to women;
You are a prettie one: and though each hower,
I am glutted, with the sacrifice of beautie,
I may be brought, as you may handle it,
To cast so good a grace and likeing on you,
You understand, come kisse me, and be joyfull,
I giue you leave.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Faith Sir, twill not shew handsome;
Our sex his blushing, full of feare, unskild too,
In these alarums.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Learne then and be perfect

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I doe beseech your honour pardon me,
And take some skilfull one, can hold you play,
I am a foole.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I tell thee maide I love thee,
Let that word make thee happie, so farr love thee,
That though I may enjoy thee without ceremony,
I will descend so lowe, to marry thee,
Me thinkes I see the race, that shall spring from us,
Some Princes, some great Souldiers

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I am afraid.
Your honours couzen'd in this calculation;
For certaine, I shall nere haue a child by you.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Because I must not thinke to marry you,
I dare not Sir, the step betwixt your honour,
And my poore humble State.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I will descend to thee,
And buoye thee up.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I'le sinke to th' Center first,
Why would your Lordship marry, and confine that pleasure,
You ever have had freely cast upon you?
Take heed my Lord this marring is a mad matter,
Lighter a paire of sheckles will hang on you,
And quieter a quartaine feaver finde you
If you wed me I must enjoy you onely,
Your eyes must be cald home, your thoughs in cages,
To sing to no eares then but mine; your hart bound
The custome, that your youth was euer nurst in,
Must be forgot, I shall forget my duty else,
And how that will appeare,

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Wee'le talke of that more

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Besides I tell yee, I am naturally,
As all young women are, that shew like handsome,
Exceeding proud, being commended, monstrous. Boy ready for the Songs
Of an unquiet temper, seldome pleas'd.
Unlesse it be with infinite observance.
Which you were never bred to; once well angerd,
As every crosse in us, provokes that passion,
And like a Sea, I roule, tosse, and chase a weeke after.
And then all mischeife I can think upon,
Abusing of your bed the least and poorest,
I tell you what you'le finde, and in these fitts,
This little beauty, you are pleased to honour,
Will be so chang'd, so alterd to an uglinesse,
To such a vizard, ten to one, I dye too,
Take't then upon my death you murderd me,

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Away, away fool, why dost thou proclaime these
To prevent that in me, thou hast chosen in another

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Him I have chosen, I can rule and master,
Temper to what I please, you are a great one
Of a strong will to bend, I dare not venture,
Be wise my Lord, and say you were well counseld,
Take mony for my ransome, and forget me,
Twill be both safe, and noble for your honour,
And wheresoever my fortunes shall conduct me,
So worthy mentions I shall render of you
So vertuous and so faire.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: You will not marry me:

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I doe beseech your honour, be not angry
At what I say, I cannot love yee, dare not;
But such a ransome, for the flowre you covet

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: No money, nor no prayers, shall redeeme that,
Not all the art you have

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Set your owne price Sir.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Goe to your wedding, neuer kneel to me
When that's done, you are mine, I will enjoy you:
Your teares do nothing, I will not loose my custome
To cast upon my selfe an Empires fortune Exit.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: My minde shall not pay this custome, cruel man

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Your body wil content me: I'le look for you, Ex.

div.stage: Enter Charino and servants in blackes. Covering the place with blackes.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Strew all your withered flowers, your Autumn sweets
By the hot Sun ravisht of bud and beauty
Thus round about her Bride-bed hang those blacks ther
The emblemes of her honour lost; all joy Bowle of wine ready.
That leades a Virgin to receive her Lover,
Keepe from this place all fellow-maides that blesse her,
And blushing and unloose her Zone, keep from her:
No merry noise nor lusty songs be heard here,
Nor ful cups crownd with wine, make the rooms giddy;
This is no masque of mirth, but murdered honour.
Sing mournfully that sad Epithalamion,
I gave thee now: and prethee let thy Lute weepe.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How now, what livery's this? doe you call this a wedding?
This is more like a funerall.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: It is one,
And my poor Daughter going to her grave,
To his most loth'd embraces that gapes for her.
Make the Earles bed ready, is the marriage done Sir?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Yes they are knit; but must this slubberdegullion
Have her maiden-head now?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: There's no avoyding it?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And there's the scaffold where she must loose it.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: The bed sir?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: No way to wipe his mouldy chaps?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: That we know

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: To any honest wel-deserving fellow,
And 'twere but to a merry Cobler, I could sit still now,
I love the game so well, but that this puckfist,
This universall rutter, fare ye well Sir;
And if you have any good prayers, put 'em forward,
There may be yet a remedy.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I wish it, Exit Rut.
And all my best devotions offer to it.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Now is this tye dispathc'd?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I thinke it be Sir:

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: And my bed ready? wine

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: There you may quickly find Sir,
Such a loth'd preparation.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Never grumble,
Nor fling a discontent upon my pleasure
It must and shall be done: give me some wine,
And fill it till it leape upon my lips:
Here's to the foolish maiden head you wot of,
The toy I must take paines for

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I beseech your Lord-ship
Load not a Fathers love,

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Pledge it Charino,
Or by my life I'le make thee pledge thy last
And be sure she be a maid, a perfect Virgin,
(I will not have my expectation dul'd)
Or your old pate goes off. I am hot and fiery
And my bloud beates alarums through my body
And fancie high. You of my guard retire,
And let me heare no noyse about the lodging
But musick and sweet ayres, now fetch your daughter,
And bid the coy wench put on all her beauties,
All her enticements, out-blush damask roses,
And dim the breaking East with her bright Christalls.
I am all on fire, away

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: And I am frozen. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Zenocia with Bow and Quiver, an Arrow bent, Arnoldo and Rutillio after her, arm'd.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Come fearelesse on

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Nay an I budge from thee
Beate me with durty sticks.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: What Masque is this?
What pretty fancy to provoke me high?
The beauteous Huntresse, fairer far, and sweeter;
Diana shewes an Ethiop to this beauty
Protected by two Virgin Knights.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: That's a lye,
A loud one, if you knew as much as I doe
The guard's dispers'd

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Fortune I hope invites us

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I can no longer hold, she puls my heart from me

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Stand, & stand fixt, move not a foote, nor speak not,
For if thou doest 'upon this point thy death sits.
Thou miserable, base, and sordid lecher,
Thou scum of noble blood, repent and speedily,
Repent thy thousand thefts, from helplesse virgins,
Their innocence betrayed to thy embraces.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: The base dishonour, that thou doest to strangers,
In glorying to abuse the lawes of marriage,
Thy Infamy thou hast flung upon thy countrey,
In nourishing this black and barbarous custome

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: My guard.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: One word more, and thou diest.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: One sillable
That tends to any thing, but I beseech you,
And as y'are Gentlemen tender my case,
And I'le thrust my javeling downe thy throate
Thou Dogg-whelpe, thou, pox upon thee, what
Should I call the? Pompean,
Thou kisse my Lady? thou scowr her chamber pot:
Thou have a mayden head? a mottly coate,
You great blinde foole, farewell and be hanged to yee,
Loose no time Lady.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Pray take your pleasure Sir,
And so wee'l take our leaves

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: We are determined,
Dye, before yield

sp.speaker: Arn
sp.l: Honour, and a faire grave

sp.speaker: Zen
sp.l: Before a lust full bed, so for our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Du cat a whee, good count, cry, preethe cry,
O what a wench hast thou lost? cry you great booby. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: And is she gone then, am I dishonoured thus
Cozend and baffuld? my guard there no man answer?
My guard I say, Sirra you knew of this plott.
Where are my guard? Ile ha' your life you villaine.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You politique old thiefe.
Heaven send her far enough Enter Guard.
And let me paye the ransome.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Did your honour call us?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Post every way, and presently recover,
The two strange Gentlemen, and the faire Lady,

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: This day was married Sir.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: We saw e'm
Making with all maine speed to'th port.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Away villains. Ex. Gard:
Recover her, or I shall dye; deale truely,
Didst not thou know,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: By all that's good I did not
If your honour meane their flight, to say I grieve for that,
Will be to lye; you may handle me as you please.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Be sure, with all the cruelty, with all the rigor,
For thou hast robd mee villaine of a treasure.

div.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: They'r all aboord, a bark rode ready for 'em,
And now are under sayle and past recovery

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Rig me a ship with all the speed that may be,
I will not loose her: thou her most false Father,
Shalt go along; and if I misse her, heare me,
Whole day will I studie to destroy thee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I shall be joyfull of it; and so you'll finde me.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Manuell du sosa. and Guiomar.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I heare, and see, too much of him, and that
Compells me Madam, though unwillingly,
To wish I had no uncles part in him,
And much I feare, the comfort of a Son
You will not long enjoy.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: 'Tis not my fault,
And therefore from his guilt my innocence
Cannot be taynted, since his Fathers death
(Peace to his soule) a Mothers prayers and care,
Were never wanting, in his education.
His child-hood I passe, as being brought up
Under my wing; and growing ripe for study,
I overcame the tendernesse, and joye
I had to looke upon him, and provided
The choicest Masters, and of greatest name
Of Salamanca, in all liberall Arts.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: To train his youth up.
I must witnesse that.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: How there he prospered, to the admiration,
Of all that knew him, for a generall scholler,
Being one of note, before he was a man,
Is still remembred in that Academy,
From thence I sent him to the Emperours court,
Attended like his Fathers Sonne and there
Maintaind him, in such bravery and height,
As did become a courtier.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Twas that spoild him, my Nephew had beene hapy
The court's a schoole indeed, in which some few
Learne vertuous principles, but most forget,
What ever they brought thither good and honest.
Trifling is there in practice, serious actions,
Are obsolete and out of use, my Nephew
Had beene a happy man, had he ne're knowne
What's there in grace, and fashion.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I have heard yet,
That while he liv'd in court, the Emperour
Tooke notice of his carriage and good parts,
The grandees did not scorne his company,
And of the greatest Ladies he was held,
A compleate Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: He indeed daunc'd well,
A turne o'th toe, with a loftie tricke or two,
To argue nimblenesse, and a strong backe,
Will go farr with a Madam: 'tis most true,
That hee's an excellent scholler, and he knowes it;
An exact courtier, and he knowes that too;
He has fought thrice, and come off still with honour,
Which he forgets not

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Nor I have much reason.
To greive his fortune that way,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are mistaken,
Prosperity does search a Gentlemans temper,
More then his adverse fortune: I have knowen
Many, and of rare parts from their successe
In private duells, rais'd up to such a pride,
And so transformed from what they were, that all
That lov'd them truely, wish'd they had fallen in them.
I need not write examples, in your sone,
'Tis too apparent; for ere Don Duarte,
Made tryall of his valour, he indeed was
Admired for civill courtesy, but now
Hee's swolne so high, out of his owne assurance,
Of what he dares do, that he seekes occasions,
Unjust occasions, grounded on blinde passion,
Ever to be in quarrels, and this makes him
Shund of all faire societies.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Would it were
In my weake power to help it: I will use
With my entreaties th' authority of a mother,
As you may of an Vncle, and enlarge it
With your command, as being a governor
To the great King in Lisborne.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Here he comes.
We are unseene, observe him.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Boye

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: What saith the spanish captaine that I strooke,
To my bold challenge?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: He refus'd to read it.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Why didst not leave it there?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I did my Lord,
But to no purpose, for he seemes more willing
To sit downe with the wrongs, then to repaire
His honour by the sword; he knowes too well,
That from your Lordship nothing can be got
But more blowes, and disgraces.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Hee's a wretch,
A miserable wretch, and all my furie
Is lost upon him; holds the masque, appointed
ith' honour of Hippolita:

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: 'Tis broke off.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: The reason?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: This was one, they heard your Lordship
Was by the Ladies choise to lead the dance,
And therefore they, too well assur'd how farr
You would out shine e'm, gave it ore and saied
They would not serve for foiles to set you off.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: They at their best are such, and ever shall be
Where I appeare.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Doe you note his modestie?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: But was there nothing else pretended?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Yes,
Young Don Alonzo, the great Captaines Nephew,
Stood on comparisons.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: With you,
And openly profess'd, that all precedence,
His birth and state considered, was due to him
Nor were your Lordship to contend with one
So farr above you.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I looke downe upon him
With such contempt and scorne, as on my slave,
Hee's a name onely, and all good in him,
He must derive, from his great grandsires ashes,
For had not their victorious acts bequeath'd,
His titles to him, and wrot on his forehead,
This is a Lord, he had liv'd unobserv'd
By any man of marke, and died as one
Among the common route, compaire with me?
'Tis giant-like ambition; I know him,
And know my selfe, that man is truely noble,
And he may justly call that worth his owne,
Which his deserts have purchac'd, I could wish
My birth were more obscure, my freinds and kinsmen
Of lesser power, or that my provident Father,
Had been like to that riotous Emperour
That chose his belly for his onely heire;
For being of no family then, and poore
My vertues whereso'er I liv'd, should make
That kingedome my inheritance.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Strange selfe love

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: For if I studied the countries lawes,
I should so easily, sound all their depth,
And rise up such a wonder, that the pleaders,
That now are in most practice, and esteeme
Should starve for want of clients: If I traveld,
Like wise Vlysses to see men and manners,
I would returne in act, more knowing, then
Homer could fancie him; If a Physitian,
So oft I would restore death wounded men,
That where I liv'd, Gallen should not be nam'd,
And he that joyn'd againe the scatterd limbs
Of torne Hippolitus should be forgotten.
I could teach Ovid courtship, how to win,
A Julia, and enjoy her, though her dower
Were all the Sun gives light to: and for armes
Were the Persian host that drank up Rivers, added
To the Turkes present powers, I could direct,
Command, and marshall them.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And yet you know not
To rule your selfe, you would not to a boy else
Like Plautus Braggart boast thus.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: All I speake,
In act I can make good,

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Why then being Master,
Of such and so good parts doe you destroy them,
With selfe opinion or like a rich miser,
Hoard up the treasures you possess, imparting,
Nor to your selfe nor others, the use of them?
They are to you, but like inchanted viands,
On which you seeme to feed, yet pine with hunger;
And those so rare perfections in my son
Which would make others happy, renders me
A wretched Mother.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are too insolent.
And those too many excellencies, that feed
Your pride, turne to a plurisy, and kill
That which should nourish vertue; dare you think
All blessings are conferd on you alone.
Ya're grosly cousend; there's no good in you,
Which others have not: are you a Scholler? so
Are many, and as knowing: are you valiant?
Waste not that courage then in braules, but spend it
In the warres, in service of your King and Countrey.

sp.speaker: Duarte.
sp.l: Yes, so I might be generall, no man lives,
That's worthy to command me

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, in Lisborne
I am: and you shall know it; every hower
I am troubled with complaints of your behaviour
From men of all conditions, and all sexes.
And my authority, which you presume
Will beare you out, in that you are my Nephew,
No longer shall protect you, for I vowe
Though all that's past I pardon, I will punish
The next fault with as much severity
As if you were a stranger, rest assur'd on't.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: And by that love you should beare, or that duty
You owe a Mother, once more I command you
To cast this hautinesse off; which if you doe,
All that is mine, is yours, if not, expect
My prayers, and vowes, for your conversion onely,
But never meanes nor favour. Exit. Manuell and Guiomar.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am tutord
As I if I were a child still, the base peasants
That feare, and envy my great worth, have done this;
But I will finde them out, I will aboord
Yet my disguise, I have too long been idle
Nor will I curbe my spirit, I was born free,
And will pursue the course best liketh me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Devide the spoile amongst you, this fair captive
I only challenge for my selfe.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: You have wonne her
And well deserve her: twenty yeares I have liv'd
A Burgesse of the Sea, and have been present
At many a desperate fight, but never saw
So small a barque with such incredible valour
So long defended, and against such odds,
And by two men scarce arm'd too.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: 'Twas a wonder.
And yet the courage they exprest being taken
And the contempt of death wan more upon me
Then all they did, when they were free: me-thinkes
I see them yet when they were brought aboord us,
Disarm'd and ready to be put in fetters
How on the suddain, as if they had sworn,
Never to taste the bread of servitude,
Both snatching up their swords, and from this Virgin,
Taking a farewell only with their eyes,
They leapt into the Sea.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: Indeed 'twas rare.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: It wrought so much on me, that but I feard,
The great ship that pursued us, our own safety
Hindring my charitable purpose to 'em,
I would have took 'em up, and with their lives
They should have had their liberties.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: O too late
For they are lost, for ever lost

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Take comfort
'Tis not impossible, but that they live yet,
For when they left the ships they were within
A league o'th shore, and with such strength and cunning
They swimming, did delude the rising billows,
With one hand making way, and with the other,
Their bloudy swords advancst, threatning the Sea-gods
With war, unlesse they brought them safely off,
That I am almost confident they live
And you again may see them.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: In that hope
I brook a wretched being, till I am
Made certaine of their fortunes, but they dead
Death hath so many doores to let out life,
I will not long survive them.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Hope the best,
And let the courteous usage you have found,
Not usuall in men of Warre perswade you
To tell me your condition.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: You know it,
A Captive, my fate and your power have made me,
Such I am now, but what I was it skills not:
For they being dead, in whom I only live
I dare not challenge family, or country
And therefore Sir enquire not, let it suffice,
I am your servant, and a thankfull servant,
(If you will call that so, which is but duty)
I ever will be, and my honour safe,
Which nobly hitherto ye have preserv'd
No slavery can appear in such a forme,
Which with a masculine constancy, I will not
Boldly looke on and suffer.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: You mistake me:
That you are made my prisoner, may prove
The birth of your good fortune. I doe finde
A winning language in your tongue and looks;
Nor can a suite by you mov'd be deni'd,
And therefore of a prisoner you must be
The Victors advocate

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: A Lady.
In whom all graces that can perfect beauty
Are friendly met, I grant that you are faire:
And had I not seen her before, perhaps
I might have sought to you

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: This I heare gladly,

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: To this incomparable Lady I will give you,
(Yet being mine, you are already hers)
And to serve her is more then to be free,
At least I think so: and when you live With her,
If you will please to think on him that brought you
To such a happinesse, for so her bountie
Will make you think her seruice, you shall euer
Make me at your devotion

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: All I can doe,
Rest you assur'd of.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: At night I'le present you,
Till when I am your guard

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Ever your servant. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: To what are we reserv'd?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Troth tis uncertaine,
Drowning we have scap'd miraculously, and
Stand faire for ought I know for hanging; money
We have none, nor ere are like to have; 'tis
To be doubted: besides we are strangers,
Wondrous hungry strangers; and charity
Growing cold, and miracles ceasing,
Without a Conjurers help, cannot finde
When we shall eate agen.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: These are no wants
If put in ballance, with Zenocias losse;
In that alone, all miseries are spoken:
O my Rutillio, when I think on her,
And that which she may suffer, being a captive,
Then I could curse my selfe, almost those powers
That send me from the fury of the Ocean.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You have lost a wife indeed, a faire and chast one,
Two blessings, not found often in one woman;
But she may be recovered, questionlesse
The ship that took us was of Portugall
And he in Lisbon, by some meanes or other
We may heare of her.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: In that hope I live.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And so do I, but hope is a poor sallad
To dine and sup with, after a two dayes fast too,
Have you no money left?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Not a Denier,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Nor any thing to pawn? 'tis now in fashion,
Having a Mistris, sure you should not be
Without a neate historicall shirt.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: For shame
Talke not so poorly.
I must talke of that
Necessity prompts us to, for beg I cannot,
Nor am I made to creep in at a window,
To filch to feed me, something must be done,
And suddenly resolve on't.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: What are these?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: One by his habite is a Jew

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: No more:
Thou art sure that's he.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Most certaine.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: How long is it
Since first she saw him?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Some two hours. Exit Ser.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Be gone— let me alone to work him.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How he eyes you,
Now he moves, towards us, in the Devills name
What would he with us?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Innocence is bold:
Nor can I feare

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: That you are poore and strangers,
I easily perceive

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: But that you'le help us,
Or any of your tribe, we dare not hope Sir.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Why think you so?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Because you are a Jew Sir,
And courtesies come sooner from the Devill
Then any of your Nation.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: We are men,
And have like you, compassion when we finde
Fit subjects for our bounty, and for proofe
That we dare give, and freely, not to you Sir,
Pray spare your paines, there's gold, stand not amaz'd,
'Tis current I assure you

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Take it man.
Sure thy good Angel is a Jew, and comes Tapers ready.
In his own shape to help thee: I could wish now,
Mine would appeare so, like a Turke.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I thank you,
But yet must tell you, if this be the prologue
To any bad act, you would have me practice
I must not take it.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: This is but the earnest
Of that which is to follow, and the bond
Which you must seale to for't, is your advancement,
Fortune with all that's in her power to give,
Offers her selfe up to you; entertaine her,
And that which Princes have kneel'd for in vaine
Presents it selfe to you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Tis above wonder

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: But far beneath the truth, in my relation
Of what you shall possesse, if you embrace it.
There is an hour in each mans life appointed
To make his happinesse if then he seize it,
And this, (in which, beyond all expectation,
You are invited to your good) is yours,
If you dare follow me, so, if not, hereafter
Expect not the like offer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Tis no vision.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis gold I'm sure. We must like brothers share,
There's for you; by this light I'me glad I have it.
There are few gallants, (for men may be such
And yet want gold, yea and sometimes silver,)
But would receive such favours from the Divel,
Though he appeared like a broker, and demanded
Sixty ith' hundred.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Wherefore should I feare,
Some plot upon my life? 'tis now to me
Not worth the keeping. I will follow him,
Farewell, wish me good fortune, we shall meete
Againe I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Or I'le ne're trust Jew more. Exit Arnoldo.
Nor Christian for his sake— plague o' my stars,
How long might I have walkt without a cloake,
Before I should have met with such a fortune?
We elder Brothers, though we are proper men,
Syavedra not the luck. Ha' too much beard, that spoiles us;
The smooth chin carries all? what's here to do now?

div.stage: Enter Duart, Alonso, and a Page.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I'le take you as I finde you:

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: That were base— you see I am unarm'd.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Out with your bodkin
Your pocket dagger, your steletto, out with it,
Or by this hand I'le kill you: such as you are
Have studied the undoing of poore Cutlers,
And made all manly weapons out of fashion:
You carry Poniards to murder men,
Yet dare not wear a sword to guard your Honour.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: that's true indeed: upon my life this gallant
Is brib'd to repeale banisht swords.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I'le shew you
The difference now, between a Spanish rapier
And your pure pisa.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Let me fetch a sword,
Upon mine honour I'le returne.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Not so Sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Or lend me yours I pray you, and take this,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: To be disgrac'd as you are, no I thank you
Spight of the fashion, while I live, I am Lights ready.
Instructed to goe arm'd: what folly 'tis
For you that are a man, to put your selfe
Into your enemies mercie.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Yield it quickly
Or I'le cut off your hand, and now disgrace you,
Thus kicke and baffle you: as you like this
You may again prefer complaints against me
To my Uncle and my Mother, and then think
To make it good with a poniard.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I am paid
For being of the fashion.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Get a sword,
Then if you dare, redeeme your reputation:
You know I am easily found: Ile adde this to it
To put you in mind.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You are too insolent,
And do insult too much on the advantage,
Of that which your unequall weapon gave you,
More then your valour.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: This to me you peasant?
Thou art not worthy of my foote poore fellow,
Tis scorne, not pitty, makes me give thee life:
Kneele down and thank me for't: how, do you stare?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have a sword Sir, you shall find, a good one;
This is no stabbing guard.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Wert thou thrice arm'd,
Thus yet I durst attempt thee:

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Then have at you,
I scorne to take blows.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: O I am slaine.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Help! murther, murther!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Shift for your selfe you are dead else,
You have kill'd the Governours Nephew.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Raise the streetes there.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: If once you are beset you cannot scape,
Will you betray your selfe?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Undone for ever. Exit Rut. & Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Who makes this out-cry,

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: O my Lord is murdered;
This way he tooke, make after him,
Help help there. Exit Page.

sp.speaker: 2. Off.
sp.l: 'Tis Don Duart.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: Pride has got a fall
He was still in quarrels, scorn'd us Peace-makers,
And all our bill-authority, now ha's paid for't.
You ha' met with your match Sir now, bring off his body
And beare it to the Governour. Some pursue
The murderer; yet if he scape, it skills not;
Were I a Prince, I would reward him for't,
He ha's ridde the City of a turbulent beast,
There's few will pitty him: but for his Mother
I truly grieve indeed, shee's a good Lady. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Hee's not i'th house,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No madam:

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Haste and seek him,
Goe all and every where, I'le not to bed
Till you returne him, take away the lights too,
The Moone lends me too much, to finde my feares,
And those devotions I am to pay
Are written in my heart, not in this booke, Kneele.
And I shall reade them there without a taper, Exit Serv.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am pursued; all the Ports are stopt too;
Not any hope to escape, behind, before me,
On either side I am beset, cursed fortune
My enemie on the Sea, and on the Land too,
Redeem'd from one affliction to another:
Would I had made the greedy waves my tombe
And dyed obscure, and innocent, not as Neroe
Smear'd ore with blood. Whither have my fears brought me?
I am got into a house, the doors all open,
This, by the largenesse of the roome, the hangings,
And other rich adornments, glistring through
The sable masque of night, sayes it belongs
To one of meanes and ranke: no servant stirring?
Murmur nor whisper?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: By the voice,
This is a woman.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Stephano, Jaspe, Julia,
Who waites there?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis the Lady of the house
I'le flie to her protection.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Speak, what are you?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Of all that ever breath'd, a man most wretched.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I am sure you are a man of most ill manners,
You could not with so little reverence else
Presse to my private chamber. Whither would you,
Or what do you seeke for?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Gracious woman heare me;
I am a stranger, and in that I answer
All your demands, a most unfortunate stranger,
That cald unto it by my enemies pride,
Have left him dead it'h streets, Justice pursues me,
And for that life, I tooke unwillingly,
And in a faire defence, I must lose mine,
Unlesse you in your charity protect me.
Your house is now my sanctuary, and the Altar,
I gladly would take hold of your sweet mercy.
By all that's deare unto you, by your vertues,
And by your innocence, that needs no forgivenesse
Take pitty on me.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Are you a Castillian:

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: No Madam, Italy claims my birth.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I ask not
With purpose to betray you, if you were
Ten thousand times a Spaniard, the nation
We Portugals most hate, I yet would save you
If it lay in my power: lift up these hangings;
Behind my Beds head there's a hollow place,
Into which enter; so, but from this stir not
If the Officers come, as you expect they will doe,
I know they owe such reverence to my lodgings
That they will easily give credit to me
And search no further.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: The blest Saints pay for me
The infinite debt I owe you.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: How he quakes?
Thus far I feele his heart beate, be of comfort,
Once more I give my promise for your safety,
All men are subject to such accidents,
Especially the valiant; and who knows not,
But that the charity I afford this stranger
My only Son else-where may stand in neede of?

div.stage: Enter Officers and servants with the body of Duart— Page.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Now Madam, if your wisedome ever could
Raise up defences against floods of sorrow
That hast to overwhelme you, make true use of
Your great discretion.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Your only sonne
My Lord Duart's slaine.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: His murtherer, pursued by us
Was by a boy discovered
Entring your house, and that induced us
To presse into it for his apprhension.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Oh?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Sure her heart is broke.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Stand off,
My sorrow is so deare and pretious to me,
That you must not partake it, suffer it Hold a purse ready.
Like wounds that do breed inward to dispatch me.
O my Duart, such an end as this
Thy pride long since did prophesie; thou art dead,
And to encrease my misery, thy sad mother?
Must make a wilfull shipwrack of her vow
Or thou fall unreveng'd. My soule's divided
And piety to a son, and true performance
Of hospitable duties to my guest,
That are to others Angels, are my furies.
Vengeance knocks at my heart, but my word given
Denies the entrance, is no medium left,
But that I must protect the murderer
Or suffer in that faith he made his Altar?
Motherly love give place, the fault made this way,
To keep a vow, to which high heaven is witnesse,
Heaven may be pleas'd to pardon.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis too late
Hee's gone, past all recovery: now reproofe
Were but unseasonable when I should give comfort,
And yet remember Sister.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O forbeare,
Search for the murtherer, and remove the body,
And as you thinke fit, give it buriall.
Wretch that I am, uncapable of all comfort,
And therefore I intreate my friends and kinsfolk,
And you my Lord, for some spare to forbeare
Your courteous visitations.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We obey you. Exeunt omnes with the body. Manet Guiomar.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: My spirits come back, and now despaire resignes
Her place againe to hope.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: What ere thou art
To whom I have given meanes of life, to witnesse
With what religion I have kept my promise,
Come fearlesse forth, but let thy face be cover'd,
That I hereafter be not forct to know thee,
For motherly affection may returne
My vow once paid to heaven. Thou hast taken from me,
The respiration of my heart, the light
Of my swoln eyes, in his life that sustain'd me,
Yet my word given to save you, I make good,
Because what you did, was not done with malice,
You are not knowne, there is no marke about you
That can discover you; let not feare betray you.
With all convenient speed you can, flie from me
That I may never see you; and that want
Of meanes may be no let unto your journie,
There are a hundred Crownes: you are at the doore now,
And so farewell for ever.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Let me first fall
Before your feete, and on them pay the duty
I owe your goodnesse; next all blessings to you,
And heaven restore the joyes I have bereft you,
With full increase hereafter, living be
The Goddesse stil'd of Hospitalitie.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Fling off these sullen cloudes, you are enterd now
Into a house of joy and hapinesse,
I have prepar'd a blessing for ye.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Thanke ye

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are peevish
And know not when ye are freinded, I have us'd those means
My state would rather aske a curse,
The Lady of this house, the noble Lady,
Will take ye as her owne, and use ye graciously:
Make much of what you are, Mistris of that beautie,
And expose it not to such betraying sorrowes:
When ye are old, and all those sweets hang witherd,
Then sit and sight

sp.speaker: Zen
sp.l: My Autum is not farr off,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Have you told your Lady

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I have told her
Both of your noble service, and your present,
Which she accepts,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I should be blest to see her.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: That now you cannot doe: she keeps her Chamber
Not well dispos'd; and has denied all visits,
The maid I have in charge to receive from ye,
So please you render her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: With all my service,
But faine I would have seene,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis but your patience;
No doubt she cannot but remember nobely.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: These three yeares I have lov'd this scornfull Lady,
And followed her with all the truth of service,
In all which time, but twice she has honoured me
With sight of her blest beauty: when you please Sir,
You may receive your charge, and tell your Lady;
A Gentleman whose life is onely dedicated,
To her commands, kisses her beauteous hands;
And Faire-one, now your helpe, you may remember
The honest courtesies, since you are mine
I ever did your modesty: you shall be neare her,
And if sometimes you name my service to her
And tell her with what noblenesse I love her,
'Twill be a gratitude I shall remember.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: What in my poore power lyes, so it be honest.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I aske no more.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You must along with me (Faire)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And so I leave you two: but to a fortune
Too happy for my fate: you shall enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Be quick, be quick, Out with the bucket there,
These sents are dull; cast richer on, and fuller;
Sente every place, where have you plas'd the musicke?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here they stand ready Sir.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: 'Tis well, be sure
The wines be lusty, high, and full of spirit,
And Amberd all.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: They are

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Give faire attendance.
In the best trim, and state, make ready all. Banquet set forth Exit.
I shall come presently againe.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: We shall Sir,
What preperation's this?
Some new devise
My Lady has in hand,

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: ô, prosper it
As long as it carries good wine in the mouth?
And good meate with it, where are all the rest

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: They are ready to attend.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sure some great person, Musicke
They would not make this hurry else.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: Harke the Musicke.
It will appeare now certaine, here it comes.
Now to our places.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Whether will he lead me?
What invitations this? to what new end,
Are these faire preperations? a rich Banquet,
Musicke, and every place stuck with adornment,
Fit for a Princes welcome; what new game
Has Fortune now prepared to shew me happie?
And then againe to sink me? 'tis no illusion.
Mine eyes are not deceiv'd, all these are reall;
What wealth and State?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Will you sit downe and eate Sir?
These carry little wonder, they are usuall;
But you shall see, if you be wise to observe it,
That that will strike indeed: strike with amazement,
Then if you be a man: this faire health to you.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What shall I see? I pledge ye Sir, I was never
So buried in amazement—

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You are so still
Drinke freely.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The very wines are admirable:
Good Sir, give me leave to aske this question,
For what great worthy man, are these prepard?
And why do you bring me hither?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: They are for you, Sir;
And under-vallve not the worth you carry,
You are that worthy man: thinke well of these.
They shall be more, and greater.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Well, blinde fortune
Thou hast the prettiest changes when thou art pleas'd,
To play thy game out wantonly—

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Come be lusty
And awake your Spirits. Cease Musick

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Good Sir, do not wake me.
For willingly I would dye in this dreame, pray whose Servants
Are all these that attend her?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: They are yours;
They wait on you,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I never yet remember
I kept such faces, nor that I was ever able
To maintaine so many.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Now you are, and shall be,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You'l say this house is mine too?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Say it? sweare it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And all this wealth?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: This is the least you see Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why, where has this been hid these thirtie yeares?
For certainely I never found I was wealthie
Till this hower, never dream'd of house, and Servants,
I had thought I had been a younger brother, a poore Gent.
I may eat boldly then.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: 'Tis prepared for ye.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The taste is perfect, and most delicate:
But why for me? give me some wine, I do drink;
I feele it sensibly, and I am here,
Here in this glorious place: I am bravely used too,
Good Gentle Sir, give me leave to thinke a little
For either I am much abus'd—

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Strike Musick
And sing that lusty Song. Musick Song.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Bewitching harmony!
Sure I am turn'd into another Creature.
Happy and blest, Arnoldo was unfortunate;
Ha? blesse mine eyes; what pretious piece of nature
To poze the world?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I told you, you would see that,
Would darken these poore preparations;
What think ye now? nay rise not, 'tis no vision.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Tis more: 'tis miracle.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You are welcome Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It speakes, and entertaines me still more glorious;
She is warme, and this is flesh here: how she stirrs me.
Blesse me what stars are there?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: May I sit neere ye?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No, you are too pure an object to behold,
Too excellent to looke upon, and live;
I must remove.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: She is a woman Sir,
Fy, what faint hart is this

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The house of wonder.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Do not you thinke your selfe now truely happie?
You have the abstract of all sweetnesse by ye,
The pretious wealth youth Labors to arrive at
Nor is she lesse in honour, then in beauty,
Ferraras, roiall Duke, is proud to call her
His best, his noblest, and most happie Sister,
Fortune has made her Mistris of herselfe,
Wealthy, and wise, without a power to sway her,
Wonder of Italy, of all harts Mistris.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: And all this is—

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Hyppolita the beauteous.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You are a poore relator of my fortunes,
Too weake a Chronicle to speak my blessings,
And leave out that essentiall part of Story
I am most high and happy in, most fortunate,
The acquaintance, and the noble fellowship
Of this faire Gentleman: pray ye do not wonder,
Nor hold it strange to heare a handsome Lady
Speak freely to ye: with your fair leave & courtesie
I will sit by ye.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I know not what to answer,
Nor where I am, nor to what end consider;
Why do you use me thus?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: are ye angry Sir,
Because ye are entertain'd with all humanity?
Freely and nobly us'd?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: No gentle Lady
That were uncivill, but it much amazes me
A stranger, and a man of no desert
Should finde such floods of courtesie.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I love ye,
I honour ye, the first and best of all men,
And where that faire opinion leads, 'tis usuall
These trifles that but serve to set off, follow,
I would not have you proud now, nor disdainful
Because I say I love ye, though I sweare it,
Nor thinke it a stale favour I fling on ye,
Though ye be handsome, and the only man
I must confesse I ever fixt mine eye on,
And bring along all promises that please us,
Yet I should hate ye then, despise ye, scorne ye,
And with as much contempt pursue your person,
As now I doe with love. But you are wiser,
At least I think, more master of your fortune,
And so I drink your health.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Hold fast good honesty,
I am a lost man else.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Now you may kisse me,
'Tis the first kisse, I ever aske, I sweare to ye.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: That I dare doe sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You doe it well too;
You are a Master Sir, that makes you coy.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Would you would send your people off.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Well thought on.
Wait all without. Exit. Zab. and servants

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I hope she is pleas'd throughly.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Why stand ye still? her'e's no man to detect ye,
My people are gon off: come, come, leave conjuring
The Spirit you would raise, is here already
Looke boldly on me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What would you have me doe?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: O most unmanly question! have you do?
Is't possible your yeares should want a Tutor?
I'le teach ye: come, embrace me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Fy stand off;
And give me leave, more now, then ere, to wonder,
A building of so goodly a proportion,
Outwardly all exact, the frame of Heaven,
Should hide within so base Inhabitants?
You are as faire, as if the morning bare ye,
Imagination never made a sweeter;
Can it be possible this frame should suffer,
And built on slight affections, fright the vewer?
Be excellent in all, as you are outward,
The worthy Mistris of those many blessings
Heaven has bestowed, make 'em appeare still nobler,
Because they are trusted to a weaker keeper.
Would ye have me love ye?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Yes,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not for your beautie;
Though I confesse, it blowes the first fire in us,
Time as he passes by, puts out that sparkle,
Nor for your wealth, although the world kneele to it,
And make it all addition to a woman,
Fortune that ruines all, makes that his conquest;
Be honest, and be vertuous, I'le admire ye,
At least be wise, and where ye lay these nets,
Strow over 'em a little modesty,
'Twill well become your cause, and catch more Fooles.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Could any one that lov'd this wholsome counsell
But love the giver more? you make me fonder:
You have a vertuous minde, I want that ornament;
Is it a sin I covet to enjoy ye?
If ye imagine I am too free a Lover,
And act that part belongs to you I am silent;
Mine eyes shall speake my blushes, parly with ye,
I will not touch your hand, but with a tremble
Fitting a vestall Nun; not long to kisse ye,
But gently as the aire, and undiscerned too,
I'le steale it thus: I'le walke your shadow by ye,
So still and silent that it shall be equall,
To put me off, as that, and when I covet,
To give such toyes as these—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A new temptation—

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Thus like the lazie minuts will I drop 'em,
Which past once are forgotten.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Excellent vice!

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Will ye be won? looke stedfastly upon me,
Looke manly, take a mans affections to you;
Young women, in the old world were not wont, Sir,
To hang out gaudy busshes for their beauties,
To talke themselues into young-mens affections;
How cold and dull you are?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How I stagger?
She is wise, as faire; but 'tis a wicked wisedome;
I'le choake before I yield.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: who waites within there Zabulon within.
Make ready the greene chamber,

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: It shall be Madam.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am afraid she will injoy me indeed,

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: What Musicke do ye love?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A modest tongue.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Wee'll have enough of that: fy, fy, how lumpish?
In a young Ladies armes, thus dull?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: For heaven sake
Profess a little goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Of what Countrey?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am of Rome.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Nay then I know you mock me,
The Italians are not frighted with such bug-bears,
Prethee go in.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am not well;

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I'le make thee,
I'le kisse thee well:

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am not sicke of that sore.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: upon my conscience, I must ravish thee,
I shall be famous for the first example:
With this I'le tye ye first, then trye your strength Sir,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My strength, away base woman? I abhor thee.
I am not caught with stales, disease dwell with thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Are ye so quicke? and have I lost my wishes?
Hoe, Zabulon; my Seruants.
Call'd ye Madam?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Is all that beautie scorned, so many sude for?
So many Princes? by a stranger too?
Must I endure this?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Wher's the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Go presently, pursue the stranger, Zabulon.
He has broke from me, Jewels I have given him:
Charge him with theft: hee has stolne my love, my freedome,
Draw him before the Governour, imprison him,
Why dost thou stay?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I'le teach him a new daunce,
For playing fast and loose with such a Lady.
Come fellowes, come: I'le execute your anger,
And to the full.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: His scorne shall feele my vengeance.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Shall I never see a lusty man againe?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Faith Mistris
You do so over-labour 'em when you have 'em,
And so dry-founder 'em, they cannot last.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Wher's the French-man?
Alas, he's all to fitters,
And lyes, taking the height of his fortune with a Sirreng.
Hee's chin'd, he's chin'd good man, he is a mourner.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: What's become of the Dane?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Who? goldy-locks?
Hee's foule i'th touch-hole; and recoiles againe,
The main Spring's weakned that holds up his cock,
He lies at the signe of the Sun, to be new breech'd.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: The Rutter too, is gone.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: O that was a brave rascall,
He would labour like a thresher: but alas
What thing can ever last? he has been ill mewd,
And drawne too soon; I have seene him in the Hospitall.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: There was an English-man.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I there was an English-man;
You'le scant finde any now, to make that name good.
There was those English that were men indeed,
And would performe like men, but now they are vanisht:
They are so taken up in their own Countrey,
And so beaten off their speed, by their own women,
When they come here, they draw their legs like hackneys:
Drinke, and their owne devices has undone 'em.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: I must have one that's strong, no life in Lisbon else,
Perfect and young: my custome with young Ladies,
And high-fed Citie dames, will fall, and breake else.
I want my selfe too, in mine age to nourish me:
They are are all sunk I maintain'd: now what's this businesse.
What goodly fellow's that?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Why do you drag me?
Pox ô your Justice; let me loose.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Not so Sir.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Cannot a man fall into one of your drunken Cellers,
And ventur the breaking on's neck, your trap-dores open
But he must be us'd thus rascally?

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: What made you wandring
So late i'th night? you know that is imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: May be I walke in my sleep.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: May be wee'l walk ye.
What made ye wandring Sir, into that vault
Where all the Citie store, and the Munition lay?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I fell into't by chance, I broke my shins for't.
Your Worships feele not that: I knockt my head
Against a hundred posts, would you had had it.
Cannot I breake my necke in mine own defence?

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: This will not serve: you cannot put it off so,
Your comming thither was to play the villaine,
To fire the powder, to blow that part oth' City.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Yes, with my nose: why were the trap-doors open?
Might not you fall, or you? had you gone that way?
I thought your Citie had sunke.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: You did your best Sir,
We must presume to help it into'th aire.
If you call that sinking: we have told you what's the law,
He that is taken there, unlesse a Magistrate,
And have command in that place, presently
If there be nothing found apparent, neare him
Worthie his torture, or his present death,
Must either pay his fine for his presumption,
(Which is sixe hundred Duckets) or for six yeares
Tug at an Oare i'th Gallies: will ye walke Sir,
For we presume you cannot pay the penalty.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Row in the Gallies, after all this mischief?

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: May be you were drunke, they'le keepe you sober there.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Tug at an Oare? you are not arrant rascals,
To catch me in a pit-fall, and betray me,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: A lusty minded man.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: A wondrous able.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Pray Gentlemen, allow me but that liberty
To speake a few words with your prisoner
And I shall thanke you.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Take your pleasure, Lady.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: What would you give that woman should redeem ye,
Redeem ye from this slavery?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Besides my service
I would give her my whole selfe, I would be her vassall.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Shee has reason to expect as much, considering
The great summe she payes for't, yet take comfort
What ye shall doe to merit this, is easie
And I will be the woman shall befriend ye,
'Tis but to entertaine some handsome Ladies,
And young faire Gentlewomen: you ghesse the way:
But giving of your mind—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am excellent at it:
You cannot picke out such another living.
I understand ye: is't not thus?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Ye have it.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Bring me a hundred of em: I'le dispatch 'em,
I will be none but yours: should another offer
Another way to redeem me, I should scorne it.
What women you shall please: I am monstrous lusty:
Not to be taken downe: would you have Children?
I'le get you those as fast, and thicke as flie-blows.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: I admire him: wonder at him.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Harke ye Lady,
You may require sometimes—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: I by my faith.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And you shall have it by my faith, & handsomly:
This old Cat wil suck shrewdly: you have no daughters?
I flye at all: now am I in my Kingdome,
Tug at an Oare? no, tug in a feather-bed,
With good warme Candles; hang your bread and water,
I'le make you young againe, beleeve that Lady.
I will so frubbish you.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Come, follow Officers,
This Gentleman is free: I'le pay the Duckets.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And when you catch me in your City-powdring-tub
Againe, boile me with Cabbidge.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: You are both warn'd and arm'd Sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Will your Ladiship weare this dressing?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Leave thy prating:
I care not what I weare.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Yet 'tis my duty
To know your pleasure, and my worst affection
To see you discontented.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Weeping too?
Prethee forgive me: I am much distemperd,
And speake I know not what: to make thee amends
The gowne that I wore yesterday, is thine;
Let it alone a while.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now you perceive,
And taste her bounty.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Much above my merit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But have you not yet found a happy time
To move for me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I have watched all occasions,
But hitherto, without successe: yet doubt not
But I'le embrace the first meanes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Do, and prosper;
Excellent creature, whose perfections make
Even sorrow lovely, if your frowns thus take me
What would your smiles doe?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Pox ô this stale Courtship:
If I have any power.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am commanded,
Obedience is the Lovers sacrifice
Which I pay gladly.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: To be forc'd to wooe,
Being a woman, could not but torment me,
But bringing for my Advocates, youth and beauty,
Set off with wealth: and then to be deni'd too
Do's comprehend all tortures. They flatterd me,
That said my lookes were charmes, my touches fetters,
My locks soft chaines, to binde the armes of Princes,
And make them in that wish'd for bondage, happy,
I am like others of a courser feature,
As weake to allure, but in my dotage, stronger:
I am no Circe; he, more then Ulysses,
Scornes all my offerd bounties, slights my favours,
And, as I were some new Egyptian, flyes me,
Leaving no pawne, but my own shame behind him.
But he shall finde, that in my fell revenge,
I am a woman: one that never pardons
The rude contemner of her profferd sweetnesse.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis done;

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: What's done?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: The uncivill stranger
Is at your suite arrested.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: 'Tis well handled.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: And under guard sent to the Governour,
With whom my testimony, and the favour,
He beares your Ladiship, have so prevail'd
That he is sentenc'd.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: To loose his head.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Is that the meanes to quench the scorching heate
Of my inrag'd desires? must innocence suffer,
'Cause I am faulty? or is my Love so fatall
That of necessity it must destroy
The object it most longs for? dull Hypollita,
To thinke that injuries could make way for love,
When courtesies were despis'd: that by his death
Thou shouldst give that, which only thou canst hope for
While he is living: My honours at the stake now,
And cannot be preserv'd, unlesse he perish
The enjoying of the thing I love, I ever
Have priz'd above my fame: why doubt I now then?
One only way is left me, to redeeme all:
Make ready my Caroch.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What will you Madam.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: And yet I am impatient of such stay:
Bind up my haire: fy, fy, while that is doing
The Law may cease his life: thus, as I am then,
Not like Hypollita, but a Bachanall
My frantique Love transports me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sure shee's distracted.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Pray you follow her: I will along with you:
I more then ghesse the cause: women that love
Are most uncertaine, and one minute crave,
What, in another they refuse to have. Exit.

div.head: Scaena 5a.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Assure thy selfe Charino, I am alter'd
From what I was; the tempests we have met with
In our uncertaine voyage, were smooth gales
Compar'd to those, the memory of my lusts
Rais'd in my conscience: and if ere againe
I live to see Zenocia, I will sue,
And seek to her as a Lover, and a Servant,
And not command affection, like a Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: In hearing this; you make me young againe,
And heaven, it seemes, favouring this good change in you
In setting of a period to our dangers
Gives us faire hopes, to find that here in Lisbon
Which hitherto in vain we long have sought for.
I have receiv'd assur'd intelligence;
Such strangers have bin seen here: and though yet
I cannot learn their fortunes, nor the place
Of their abode, I have a soule presages
A fortunate event here.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: There have pass'd
A mutuall enterchange of courtesies
Between me, and the Governour; therfore boldly
We may presume of him, and of his power
If we finde cause to use them, otherwise
I Would not be known here, and these disguises
Will keep us from discovery.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What are these?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The Governour: with him my Rivall, bound.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: For certaine 'tis Arnoldo.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Let's attend
What the successe will be.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is't possible
There should be hope of his recovery,
His wounds so many and so deadly?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: So they appear'd at first, but the blood stop'd,
His trance forsook him, and on better search
We found they were not mortall;

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Use all care
To perfect this unhop'd for cure: that done
Propose your own rewards; and till you shall
Heare farther from me, for some ends I have,
Conceal'd it from his Mother.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Wee'l not faile Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You stil stand confident on your innocence.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: It is my best and last guard, which I will not
Leave, to relye on your uncertaine mercy.

div.stage: Enter Hypolita, Zabulon, Leopold, Zenocia, 2 Servants.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Who bade you follow me! Goe home, & you Sir,
As you respect me, goe with her.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Zenocia?
And in her house a Servant?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: 'Tis my daughter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: My love? Contain your joy, observe the sequel. Zen. passes

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Fye Madam, how undecent 'tis for you.
So far, unlike your selfe to bee seene thus
In th'open streets? why do you kneele? pray you rise,
I am acquainted with the wrong, and losse
You have sustain'd, and the Delinquent now
Stands ready for his punishment.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Let it fall Sir,
On the offender: he is innocent
And most unworthy of these bonds he weares,
But I made up of guilt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What strange turne's this?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: This was my prisoner once.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: If chastity
In a young man, and tempted to the height too
Did ere deserve reward, or admiration,
He justly may claim both. Love to his person
(Or if you please give it a fowler name)
Compel'd me first to train him to my house,
All engines I rais'd there to shake his vertue,
Which in the assault were uselesse; he unmov'd stil
As if he had no part of humane frailty,
Against the nature of my Sex, almost
I plaid the Ravisher. You might have seen
In our contention, young Apollo fly
And love-sicke Daphne follow, all arts failing,
By flight he wan the victory, breaking from
My scorn'd embraces: the repulse (in women
Unsufferable) invited me to practise
A meanes to be reveng'd: and from this grew
His Accusation, and the abuse
Of your still equall justice: My rage ever
Thanks heaven, though wanton, I found not my selfe
So far engag'd to hell, to prosecute
To the death what I had plotted, for that love
That made me first desire him, then accuse him,
Commands me with the hazard of my selfe
First to entreate his pardon, then acquit him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What ere you are, so much I love your vertue
That I desire your friendship: doe you unloose him
From those bonds, you are worthy of, your repentance
Makes part of satisfaction; yet I must
Severely reprehend you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am made
A stale on all parts: But this fellow shall
Pay dearely for her favour.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: My life's so full
