Of various changes, that I now despaire
Of any certaine port; one trouble ending,
A new, and worse succeeds it: what should Zenocia
Doe in this womans house? Can chastity
And hot Lust dwell together without infection?
I would not be or jealous, or secure,
Yet something must be done, to sound the depth on't:
That she lives is my blisse, but living there,
A hell of torments; there's no way to her
In whom I live, but by this door, through which
To me, 'tis death to enter, yet I must,
And will make tryall.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Let me hear no more
Of these devices, Lady: this I pardon,
And at your intercession I forgive
Your instrument the Jew too: get you home.
The hundred thousand crowns you lent the City
Towards the setting forth of the last Navy
Bound for the Islands, was a good then, which
I ballance with your ill now.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Now Sir, to him,
You know my daughter needs it.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Let me take
A farewell with mine ey, Sir, though my lip,
Be barr'd the Ceremonie, courtesie
And custome too allowes of.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Gentle Madam,
I neither am so cold, nor so ill bred
But that I dare receive it: you are unguarded,
And let me tell you that I am asham'd
Of my late rudeness, and would gladly therefore
If you please to accept my ready service
Waite on you to your house.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Above my hope:
Sir, if an Angel were to be my convoy
He should not be more welcome.— Exit Arn. and Hyp.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Now you know me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and honour you: ever remembring
Your many bounties, being ambitious only
To give you cause to say by some one service
That I am not ungratefull.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: 'Tis now offer'd:
I have a suite to you, and an easie one,
Which e're long you shall know.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: When you think fit Sir,
And then as a command; I will receive it,
Till when, most welcome: you are welcome too Sir,
'Tis spoken from the heart, and therefore needs not
Much protestation: at your better leysure
I will enquire the cause that brought you hither:
In the meane time serve you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You out-doe me Sir. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Duart.
sp.l: You have bestowed on me a second life
For which I live your creature, and have better'd
What nature fram'd unperfect, my first being
Insolent pride made monstrous; but this later
In learning me to know my selfe, hath taught me
Not to wrong others.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Then we live indeed.
When we can goe to rest without a larum
Given every minute to a guilt-sick conscience
To keep us waking, and rise in the morning
Secure in being innocent: but when
In the remembrance of our worser actions
We ever beare about us whips and furies,
To make the day a night of sorrow to us,
Even life's a burthen.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I have found and felt it;
But will endeavour having first made peace
With those intestine enemies my rude passions
To be so with man-kinde: but worthy Doctor,
Pray if you can resolve me; was the Gentleman
That left me dead, ere brought unto his tryall?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Nor known, nor apprehended.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: That's my griefe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Why doe you wish he had been punished?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: No,
The streame of my swoln sorrow runs not that way:
For could I finde him, as I vow to heaven
It shall be my first care to seek him out,
I would with thankes acknowledge that his sword,
In opening my veines, which proud bloud poison'd,
Gave the first symptomes of true health.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: 'Tis in you
A Christian resolution: that you live
Is by the Governours, your Uncles charge
As yet conceal'd. And though a sons losse never
Was solemniz'd with more teares of true sorrow
Then have been paid by your unequald Mother
For your supposed death, shee's not acquainted
With your recovery.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: For some few dayes
Pray let her so continue: thus disguis'd
I may abroad unknown.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Without suspition
Of being discovered

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am confident
No moisture sooner dies then womens teares,
And therefore though I know my Mother vertuous,
Yet being one of that fraile sex I purpose
Her farther tryall.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: That as you thinke fit— I'le not betray you

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: To finde out this stranger
This true Phisician of my mind and manners
Were such a blessing. He seem'd poore, and may
Perhaps be now in want; would I could finde him.
The Innes I'le search first, then the publique Stewes
He was of Italy, and that Countrey breeds not
Precisians that way, but hot Libertines;
And such the most are: 'tis but a little travaile:
I am unfurnisht too, pray Mr. Doctor,
Can you supply me?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: With what summe you please.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I will not be long absent.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: That I wish too;
For till you have more strength, I would not have you
To be too bold.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Feare not, I will be carefull. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I have brought him Sir, a fellow that will do it
Though Hell stood in his way, ever provided
You pay him for't.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: He had a strange aspect
And lookes much like the figure of a hang-man
In a table of the Passion.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: He transcends,
All presidents beleeve it, a flesh'd ruffian,
That hath so often taken the Strappado,
That 'tis to him, but as a lofty tricke
Is to a tumbler: he hath perused too,
All Dungeons in Portugall, thrice seven yeares
Rowed in the Galleys for three severall murthers,
Though I presume that he has done a hundred,
And scapt unpunisht.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: He is much indebt to you,
You set him off so well. What will you take Sir
To beate a fellow for me, that thus wrongd me?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: To beate him say you?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Yea, beate him to lamenesse,
To cut his lips or nose off; any thing,
That may disfigure him.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Let me consider?
Five hundred pistollets for such a service
I thinke were no deare penniworth.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Five hundred!
Why there are of your brother-hood in the Citie,
Ile undertake shall kill a man for twenty.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Kill him? I think so; Ile kill any man
For halfe the money.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: And will you aske more
For a sound beating then a murther?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I Sir,
And with good reason, for a dog that's dead
The Spanish proverb saies, will never bite:
But should I beate or hurt him only, he may
Recover, and kill me.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: A good conclusion,
The obduracie of this rascall makes me tender.
I'le runne some other course, there's your reward,
Without the employment.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: For that as you please Sir;
When you have need to kill a man, pray use me,
But I am out at beating. Exit.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: What's to be done then?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: I'le tell thee Zabulon, and make thee privy
To my most neare designes: this stranger, which
Hyppolita so doates on, was my prisoner
When the last Virgin, I bestowed upon her,
Was made my prize? how he escap'd, hereafter
I'le let thee know; and it may be the love
He beares the servant, makes him scorne the Mistris.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: 'Tis not unlike; for the first time he saw her
His lookes exprest so much, and for more proofe
Since he came to my Ladies house, though yet
He never knew her, he hath practis'd with me
To help him to a conference, without
The knowledge of Hyppolita; which I promis'd.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: And by all meanes performe it, for their meeting,
But worke it so, that my disdainfull Mistris
(Whom, notwithstanding all her injuries
'Tis my hard fate to love) may see and heare them.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: To what end Sir?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: This Zabulon: when she sees
Who is her rivall, and her Lovers basenesse
To leave a Princesse for her bondwoman,
The sight make her scorne, what now she doates on,
I'le double thy reward.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You are like to speed then:
For I confesse what you will soone beleeve,
We serve them best that are most apt to give.
For you I'le place you where you shall see all, and yet be unobserv'd.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Tat I desire too. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I cannot see her yet, how it afflicts me:
The poyson of this place, should mixe it selfe
With her pure thoughts? 'Twas she that was commanded
Or my eyes failed me grosly; that youth, that face
And all that noble sweetnesse. May shee not live here,
And yet be honest still?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: It is Arnoldo,
From all his dangers free; fortune I blesse thee,
My noble husband! how my joy swells in me,
But why in this place? what businesse hath he here?
He cannot heare of me, I am not known here.
I left him vertuous; how I shake to thinke now?
And how that joy I had, cooles, and forsakes me?
This Lady is but faire, I have beene thought so
Without compare admired; Shee has bewitched him
And he forgot—

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: 'Tis she againe, the same— the same Zenocia.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: There they are together.— Now you may mark

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Peace let 'em parly.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: That you are well Zenocia; and once more,
Blesse my despairing eyes, with your wisht presence,
I thanke the gods; but that I meete you here—

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: They are acquainted,

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I found that secret Madam,
When you commanded her goe home: pray heare 'em.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: That you meet me here, ne're blush at that Arnoldo.
Your comming comes too late: I am a woman,
And one woman with another may be trusted;
Do you feare the house?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: More then a feare, I know it,
Know it not good, not honest.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: What do you here then?
I'th name of vertue why doe you approach it?
Will you confesse the doubt and yet pursue it?
Where have your eyes been wandring my Arnoldo?
What constancy, what faith do you call this? Fie,
Aime at one wanton marke, and wound another?
I doe confesse, the Lady faire, most beauteous, Leopold places himself unseen below.
And able to betray a strong mans liberty,
But you that have a love, a wife— you do well
To deale thus wisely with me: yet Arnoldo,
Since you are pleas'd to studie a new beauty,
And think this old and ill, beaten with misery.
Studie a nobler way for shame to love me,
Wrong not her honesty.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You have confirm'd me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Who though shee be your wife, will never hinder you,
So much I rest a servant to your wishes,
And love your Loves, though they be my destructions,
No man shall know me, nor the share I have in thee,
No eye suspect, I am able to prevent you,
For since I am a slave to this great Lady,
Whom I perceive you follow

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Be not blinded.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Fortune shall make me useful to your service,
I will speake for you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Speake for me? you wrong me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I will endeavour all the wayes I am able
To make her think well of you; will that please,
To make her dote upon you, dote to madnesse,
So far against my selfe I will obey you.
But when that's done, and I have shewed this duty
This great obedience, few will buy it at my price,
Thus will I shake hands with you, wish you well,
But never see you more, nor receive comfort
From any thing, Arnoldo.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You are too tender;
I neither doubt you, nor desire longer
To be a man, and live, then I am honest
And only yours; our infinite affections
Abus'd us both.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Where are your favours now?
The courtesies you shew'd this stranger, Madam?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Have I now found the cause?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Attend it further.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Did she invite you doe you say?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Most cunningly,
And with a preparation of that state
I was brought in and welcom'd.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Seem'd to love you?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Most infinitly, at first sight, most dotingly.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Shee is a goodly Lady;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Wondrous handsome:
At first view, being taken unprepar'd,
Your memory, not present then to assist me,
Shee seem'd so glorious sweet, and so far stird me,
Nay be not jealous, there's no harme done.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Prethee— didst thou not kisse Arnoldo?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Yes faith did I.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: And then—

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I durst not, did not—

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I forgive you,
Come tell the truth.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: May be I lay with her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: He mocks me too, most basely.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Did yee faith? did ye forget so far?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Come, come, no weeping;
I would have lyen first in my grave, beleeve that.
Why will you aske those things you would not heare?
Shee is too untemperate to betray my vertues
Too openly lascivious: had she dealt
But with that seeming modesty she might,
And flung a little Art upon her ardor,
But 'twas forgot, and I forgot to like her,
And glad I was deceiv'd. No my Zenocia,
My first love here begun, rests here unreapt yet,
And here for ever.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: You have made me happy,
Even in the midst of bondage blest.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You see now
What rubs are in your way.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: And quickly Zabulon
I'le roote 'em out.— Be sure you do this presently.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Doe not you alter then.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: I am resolute. Exit Zab.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: To see you only I came hither last,
Drawne by no love of hers, nor base allurements,
For by this holy light I hate her heartily.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: I am glad of that you have sav'd me so much vengeance
And so much feare
From this hour, faire befall you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Some meanes I shall make shortly to redeem you,
Till when, observe her well, and fit her temper,
Only her lust contemn.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: When shal I see you?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I will live here abouts, and bear her faire stil,
Till I can finde a fit houre to redeeme you.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Shut all the dores;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: We are betray'd,
The Lady of the house has heard our parley,
Seene us, and seen our Loves.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You courteous Gallant,
You that scorn all I can bestow, that laugh at
The afflictions, and the grones I suffer for you,
That slight and jeere my love, contemn the fortune,
My favours can fling on you, have I caught you?
Have I now found the cause? yee foole my wishes?
Is mine own slave, my bane? I nourish that
That sucks up my content. I'le pray, no more,
Nor wooe no more; thou shalt see foolish man,
And to thy bitter paine and anguish, looke on
The vengeance I shall take, provok'd and sleighted;
Redeem her then, and steale her hence: ho Zabulon
Now to your worke.

div.stage: Enter Zabulon and servants, some holding Arnoldo, some ready with a cord to strangle Zenocia.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Lady, but heare me speake first,
As you have pitty.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I have none. You taught me,
When I even hung about your necke, you scorn'd me.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Shall we pluck yet?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: No, hold a little Zabulon,
I'le pluck his heart-strings first: now am I worthy
A little of your love?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I'le be your servant,
Command me through what danger you shall aime at,
Let it be death.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Be sure Sir, I shall fit you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But spare this Virgin;

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I would spare that villain first,
Had cut my Fathers throate.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Bounteous Lady,
If in your sexe there be that noble softnesse,
That tendernesse of heart, women are crown'd for—

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Kneele not Arnoldo, doe her not that honour,
She is not worthy such submission,
I scorne a life depends upon her pitty.
Proud woman do thy worst, and arme thy anger,
With thoughts as blacke as hell, as hot and bloody,
I bring a patience here, shall make 'em blush,
An innocence, shall outlook thee, and death too.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Make me your slave, I give my freedome to ye,
For ever to be fetterd to your service;
'Twas I offended, be not so unjust then,
To strike the innocent, this gentle maid,
Never intended feare and doubt against you:
Shee is your servant, pay not her observance
With cruell looks, her duteous faith with death.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Am I faire now? now am I worth your liking?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Not faire, not to be liked, thou glorious Divell,
Thou vernisht piece of lust, thou painted fury.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Speake gently sweet, speak gently;

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I'le speak nobly.
'Tis not the saving of a life I aime at,
Marke me lascivious woman, mark me truly,
And then consider, how I weigh thy angers.
Life is no longer mine, nor deare unto me,
Then usefull to his honour, I preserve it
If thou hadst studied all the courtesies
Humanity and noble blood, ar linkt too,
Thou couldst not have propounded such a benefit,
Nor heapt upon me such unlookt for honour
As dying for his sake, to be his Martyr,
'Tis such a grace.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You shall not want that favour,
Let your bones worke miracles.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Dear Lady
By those faire eyes—

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: There is but this way left ye
To save her life.—

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Speake it, and I embrace it.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Come to my private chamber presently
And there, what love and I command—

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I'le doe it,
Be comforted Zenocia.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Do not do this,
To save me, do not loose your selfe I charge you,
I charge you by your love, that love you beare me;
That love, that constant love you have twin'd to me,
By all your promises, take heed you keep 'em,
Now is your constant tryall. If thou dost this,
Or mov'st one foote, to guide thee to her lust,
My curses and eternall hate pursue thee.
Redeem me at the base price of disloyalty?
Must my undoubted honesty be thy bawd too?
Goe and entwine thy selfe about that body?
Tell her, for my life thou hast lost thine honour,
Pulld all thy vowes from heaven, basely, most basely
To add an hour to me that hate thee for it,
Stoop'd to the servile flames of that foule woman
Know thee againe, nor name thee for a husband.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: What shall I doe to save her?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: How now, what hast there?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Governour, attended with some Gentlemen,
Are newly entered, to speake with your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Poxe ô their businesse, reprieve her for this hour,
I shall have other time.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Now fortune help us.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: I'le meete 'em presently: retire a while all. Exit.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You rise to day upon your right side Lady;
You know the danger too, and may prevent it,
And if you suffer her to perish thus,
As she must doe, and suddenly beleeve it,
Unlesse you stand her friend; you know the way on't,
I ghesse you poorely love her, lesse your fortune.
Let her know nothing, and performe this matter,
There are hours ordained for severall businesses,
You understand.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I understand you bawd Sir,
And such a Councellour I never car'd for.

div.stage: Enter the Governour, Clodio, Leopold, Charino and Attendants at one doore, Hyppolita at the other.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Your Lordship does me honour.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Faire Hyppolita,
I am come to ease you of a charge.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I keepe none,
I count a burthen Sir: and yet I lye too.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Which is the maide; is she here?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Yes Sir,
This is she, this is Zenocia,
The very same I sued to your Lordship for.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Clodio againe? more misery? more ruine?
Under what angry starre is my life govern'd.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Come hither maid, you are once more a free woman
Here I discharge your bonds.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Another smile,
Another tricke of fortune to betray us!

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Why do's your Lordship use me so unnobly?
Against my will, to take away my bond-woman?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: She was no lawfull prize, therefore no bond-woman:
She's of that Countrey we hold friendship with,
And ever did, and therefore to be used
With entertainment, faire and courteous.
The breach of league in us gives foule example,
Therefore you must be pleas'd to think this honest;
Did you know what she was?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Not till this instant;
For had I known her, she had been no prisoner.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: There, take the maid, she is at her owne dispose now,
And if there be ought else to do your honour
Any poore service in—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I am vowed your servant;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Your Father's here too, that's our only comfort,
And in a Countrey now, we stand free people,
Where Clodio has no power, be comforted.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I feare some trick yet.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Be not so dejected.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: You must not be displeas'd; so farewell Lady.
Come Gentlemen; Captain, you must with me too,
I have a little businesse.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: I attend your Lordship:
Now my way's free, and my hopes. Lords againe.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Dy'e jeere me now ye are going?
I may live yet— to make you howle both.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You might have done; you had power then,
But now the chaines are off, the command lost,
And such a story they will make of this
To laugh out lazie time.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: No meanes yet left me?
For now I burst with anger: none to satisfie me?
No comfort? no revenge?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You speake too late;
You might have had all these, your usefull servants
Had you been wise, and suddain; What power, or will
Over her beauty, have you now? by violence
To constrain his love; she is as free as you are,
And no law can impeach her liberty,
And whilst she is so, Arnoldo will despise you.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Either my love or anger must be satisfied,
Or I must dye.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I have a way woo'd do it,
Woo'd do it yet, protect me from the Law.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: From any thing; thou knowest what power I have
What money, and what friends.

sp.speaker: Zab
sp.l: 'Tis a divellish one:
But such must now be us'd: walke in, I'le tell you;
And if you like it, if the Divell can doe any thing.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Divell, or what thou wilt, so I be satisfied. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: This is the rarest, and the lustiest fellow,
And so bestirs himselfe—

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Give him breath Mistris
You'l melt him else.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: He does perform such wonders—
The women are mad on him.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Give him breath I say;
The man is but a man, he must have breath.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: How many had he yesterday?
And they paid bravely too.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: About fourteene.
But still I cry give breath, spare him and have him.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Five Dames to day; this was a small stage
He may endure five more.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Breath, breath I cry still;
Body ô me give breath, the man's a lost man else.
Feede him and give him breath. Enter 2. Gentlewomen

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Welcome Gentlewomen,
Y'are very welcome.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: We heare you have a lusty & wel-complexion'd fellow
That does rare tricks, my sister and my selfe here,
Would trifle out an houre or two so, please you.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Jaques, conduct 'em in.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: There's for your courtesie. Exeunt Jaqu. and Gent.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Good pay stil, good round pay, this happy fellow
Will set me up againe; he brings in gold
Faster then I have leisure to receive it.
O that his body were not flesh and fading;
But I'le so papp him up— nothing too deare for him;
What a sweet sent he has?— Now what newes Jaques?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: He cannot last, I pitty the poor man
I suffer for him; two coaches of young City dames,
And they drive as the Divell were in the wheeles,
Are ready now to enter: and behind these
An old dead-palsied Lady in a litter,
And she makes all the hast she can: the man's lost,
You may gather up his dry bones to make nine-pins,
But for his flesh.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: These are but easie labours,
Yet, for I know he must have rest.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: He must:— you'l beate him off his leggs else presently.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Goe in, and bid him please himselfe, I am pleas'd too:
To morrow's a new day; but if he can
I would have him take pity ô the old Lady.
Alas 'tis charity.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I'le tell him all this
And if he be not too fool-hardy.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: How now?
What newes with you?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You must presently
Shew all the art you have, and for my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: She may command.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You must not dream nor trifle.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Which way?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: A spell you must prepare, a powerfull one,
Peruse but these directions, you shall find all;
There is the picture too, be quicke, and Faithfull,
And do it with that strength— When 'tis perform'd
Pitch your reward at what you please, you have it.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Ile do my best, and suddainly: but hark ye,
Will you never lye at home againe?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Excuse me,
I have too much businesse yet.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I am right glad on't.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Think on your businesse, so farewell.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I'le do it.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Within this houre I'le visit you againe
And give you greater lights.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I shall observe ye;
This brings a brave reward, bravely I'le do it
And all the hidden art I have, express in't. Ex. at both dores.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Now do I look as if I were Crow-trodden,
Fy how my hams shrinke under me; ô me,
I am broken-winded too; Is this a life?
Is this the recreation I have aimd at,
I had a body once, a handsome body,
And wholsome too. Now I appeare like a rascall
That had been hung a yeare or two in gibbets.
Fye how I faint; Women? keep me from women;
Place me before a Cannon, 'tis a pleasure;
Stretch me upon a rac it, a recreation;
But women? women? ô the Divell! women?
Curtius gulfe was never halfe so dangerous.
Is there no way to finde the trap-dore againe,
And fall into the Cellar, and be taken?
No lucky fortune to direct me that way?
No galleys to be got, nor yet no gallows?
For I feare nothing now, no earthly thing
But these unsatisfied Men-leeches, women.
How divellishly my bones ake: ô the old Lady!
I have a kind of waiting-woman, lyes crosse my back too,
O how she stings! no treason to deliver me?
Now what are you? do you mock me?
No Sir, no,
We were your Predecessors in this place,
And come to see you beare up.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen;
You seem to have a snuffing in your head Sir,
A parlous snuffing, but this same dampish aire—
A dampish aire indeed.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Blow your face tenderly,
Your nose will ne're endure it: mercy ô me,
What are men change'd to here? is my nose fast yet?
Mee thinks it shakes it'h hilts: pray tell me Gentlemen,
How long is't since you flourisht here?
Not long since.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Move your selfe easily, I see you are tender,
Nor long endured.
The labour was so much Sir
And so few to perform it.—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Must I come to this?
And draw my legs after me like a lame dog?
I cannot run away, I am too feeble:
Will you sue for this place againe Gentlemen?

sp.p: No truly sir, the place has been too warm for our complexions.

sp.l: We have enough on't, rest you merry sir,
We came but to congratulate your fortune,
You have abundance.
Beare your fortune soberly,
And so we leave you to the next faire Lady. Exit the 3.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Stay but a little, and I'le meet you Gentlemen,
At the next Hospitall: ther's no living thus,
Nor am I able to endure it longer,
With all the helps and heates that can be given me,
I am at my trot already; they are faire and young
Most of the women that repaire unto me,
But they stick on like burs, shake me like feathers.
More women yet?
Would I were honestly married,
To any thing that had but halfe a face,
And not a groate to keep her, nor a smocke,
That I might be civilly merry when I pleased,
Rather then labouring in these fulling mills.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: By this the spell begins to worke: you are lusty,
I see you beare up bravely yet.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Doe you heare Lady,
Do not make a game-beare of me, to play me hourly,
And fling on all your whelps; it will not hold;
Play me with some discretion; to day one course,
And two dayes hence another.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: If you be so angry
Pay backe the money I redeem'd you at
And take your course; I can have men enough:
You have lost me an hundred crowns since you came hither,
In broths and strengthning caudles; till you do pay me
If you will eate and live, you shall endeavour,
I'le chain you to't else.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Make me a dog-ken 〈…〉
I'le keep your house and bark, 〈◊〉 feed on bare bones,
And be whipt out a dores,
Doe you mark me Lady? whipt,
I'le eate old shoes. Enter Duart.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: In this house, I am told
There is a stranger, of a goodly person,
And such a one there was; if I could see him,
I yet remember him.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Your businesse Sir,
If it be for a woman, ye are cozend,
I keepe none here. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Certain this is the Gentleman,
The very same.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Death, if I had but money,
Or any friend to bring me from this bondage,
I would thrash, set up a Coblers shop, keepe hogs,
And feede with 'em, sell tinder boxes,
And Knights of Ginger-bread, thatch for three
Halfe pence a day, and thinke it Lordly,
From this base stallion trade: Why does he cy me,
Eye me so narrowly?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: It seemes you are troubled Sir,
I heard you speak of want;

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis better hearing
Far, then releiving Sir?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I do not think so, you know me not.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Not yet that I remember.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: You shall, and for your friend: I am beholding to yee
Greatly beholding Sir, If you remember,
You fought with such a man, they cal'd Duart,
A proud distemper'd man: he was my enemie,
My mortall foe, you slew him fairly, nobly.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Speake softly Sir, you do not meane to betray me
I wisht the Gallows, now th'are comming fairely.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Be confident, for as I live, I love you,
And now you shall perceive it: for that service
Me, and my purse command: there, take it to ye,
'Tis gold, and no small sum, a thousand duckets,
Supply your want.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: But do you do this faithfully?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: If I mean ill, spit in my face and kicke me,
In what else I may serve you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I thanke you,
This is as strange to me as Knights adventure.
I have a project, 'tis an honest one,
And now I'le tempt my fortune.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Trust me with it.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You are so good and honest I must trust ye,
'Tis but to carry a letter to a Lady
That sav'd my life once.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: That will be most thankfull,
I will do't with all care.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Where are you, white-broth?
Now lusty blood,
Come in, and tell your money:
'Tis ready here, no threats, nor no orations,
Nor prayers now.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: You do not meane to leave me—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'le live in hell sooner then here, and cooler.
Come quickly come, dispatch, this ayers unwholsome:
Quickly good Lady, quickly to't.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Well, since it must be,
The next, I'le fetter faster sure, and closer.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And picke his bones, as y'are done mine, poxe take ye.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: At my lodging for a while, you shall be quarterd,
And there take physick for your health.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I thanke ye
I have found my Angel now too, if I can keepe him.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You like the Letter.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Yes, but I must tell you,
You tempt a desperate hazard, to sollicite
The mother, (and the grieved one too, 'tis rumord)
Of him you slew so lately.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have told you
Some proofes of her affection, and I know not
A neerer way to make her satisfaction
For a lost Sonne, then speedily to help her
To a good husband; one that will beget
Both sons and daughters, if she be not barren.
I have had a breathing now, and have recovered
What I lost in my late service, 'twas a hot one:
It fir'd and fir'd me; but all thanks to you Sir,
You have both freed and cool'd me.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: What is done Sir
I thought well done, and was in that rewarded,
And therefore spare your thanks.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'le no more whoring:
This fencing twixt a paire of sheets, more weares one
Then all the exercise in the world besides.
To be drunk with good Canary, a meere Julip
Or like gourd-water to 't; twenty surfets
Come short of one nights work there. If I get this Lady
As ten to one I shall; I was ne're denied yet,
I will live wondrous honestly; walk before her
Gravely, and demurely
And then instruct my family; you are sad,
What do you muse on Sir?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Truth I was thinking
What course to take for the delivery of your letter,
And now I have it: but faith did this Lady
(For do not gull your selfe) for certain know,
You kild her sonne?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Give me a booke, I'le swear't;
Denyed me to the Officers, that pursued me,
Brought me her selfe to'th dore, then gave me gold
To beare my charges, and shall I make doubt then
But that she lov'd me? I am confident
Time having tane her griefe off, that I shall be
Most welcome to her: for then to have wooed her
Had been unseasonable.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: well Sir, there's more money,
To make you handsome; I'le about your businesse:
You know where you must stay.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: There you shall finde me:
Would I could meete my brother now, to know,
Whither the Jew, his Genius, or my Christian,
Has prov'd the better friend. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: O who would trust
Deceiving woman! or beleeve that one
The best, and most canoniz'd ever was
More then a seeming goodnesse! I could raile now
Against the sexe, and curse it; but the theame
And way's too common: yet that Guiomar
My mother; (nor let that forbid her to be
The wonder of our nation) she that was
Mark'd out the great example, for all Matrons
Both wife and Widow; shee that in my breeding
Exprest the utmost of a mothers care,
And tendernesse to a sonne; she that yet faines
Such sorrow for me; good God, that this mother,
After all this, should give up to a stranger,
The wreake she owed her sonne; I feare her honour.
That he was sav'd, much joyes me, and grieve only
That she was his preserver. I'le try further,
And by this Engine, find whether the teares,
Of which, she is so prodigall, are for me,
Or us'd to cloake her base hypocrisy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Are you assur'd the charme prevailes?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Do I live?
Or you speake to me? Now, this very instant
Health takes its last leave of her; maugre palenesse
Like winter, nips the Roses and the lillies,
The Spring that youth, and love adorn'd her face with.
To force affection, is beyond our art,
For I have prov'd all meanes that hell has taught me,
Or the malice of a woman, which exceeds it,
To change Arnoldoe's love, but to no purpose:
But for your bond-woman.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Let her pine and dye;
She remov'd; which like a brighter sun,
Obscures my beames, I may shine out againe,
And as I have been, be admir'd and sought to:
How long has she to live?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Lady, before
The Sun twice rise and set, be confident,
She is but dead; I know my Charme hath found her
Nor can the Governours guard; her lovers teares;
Her Fathers sorrow, or his power that freed her,
Defend her from it.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: All things have succeeded,
As you could wish; I saw her brought sick home;
The image of pale death, stampt on her fore-head.
Let me adore this second Hecate,
This great Commandresse, of the fatall sisters,
That as she pleases, can cut short, or lengthen
The threed of life.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Where was she, when the inchantment
First ceas'd upon her.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Taking the fresh aire,
In the company of the Governour, and Count Clodio
Arnoldo too, was present with her Father,
When, in a moment (so the servants told me)
As she was giving thanks to the Governour,
And Clodio, for her unexpected freedome,
As if she had been blasted, she sunk down,
To their amazement.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: 'Tis thy master-piece
Which I will so reward, that thou shalt fixe here,
And with the hazard of thy life, no more
Make tryall of thy powerfull Art; which known
Our Lawes call death: off with this Magicall robe,
And be thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Stand close, you shall heare more.

sp.speaker: Go: Man.
sp.l: You must have patience; all rage is vain now,
And piety forbids, that we should question
What is decreed above, or aske a reason
Why heaven determines this or that way of us.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Heaven has no hand in't; 'tis a work of hell.
Her life hath been so innocent, all her actions
So free from the suspition of crime,
As rather she deserves a Saints place here,
Then to endure, what now her sweetenesse suffers.

sp.speaker: Charin.
sp.l: Not for her fault, but mine Sir; Zenocia suffers,
The sin I made, when I sought to rase downe
Arnoldos love, built, on a Rock of truth,
Now to the height is punish'd. I professe,
Had he no birth, nor parts, the present sorrowes
He now expresses for her, does deserve her
Above all Kings, though such had been his riuals.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: All Ancient stories, of the love of husbands
To vertuous wives, be now no more remembred.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The tales of Turtles, ever be forgotten,
Or, for his sake beleev'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I have heard, there has been
Betweene some married paires, such sympathy,
That th' husband, has felt really, the throwes
His wife then teeming suffers, this true griefe,
Confirms, 'tis not impossible.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Wee shall finde
Fit time for this hereafter; lets 'use now
All possible meanes to help her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Care, nor cost,
Nor what Physitians can do, shall be wanting;
Make use of any meanes, or men.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You are noble. Exeunt. Man. Clod. Charino.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Ten Colledges of Doctors shall not save her.
Her fate is in your hand.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Can I restore her?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: If you command my Art.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'le dye my selfe first.
And yet I'le goe visit her, and see
This miracle of sorrow in Arnoldo:
And 'twere for me, I should change places with her,
And dye most happy, such a lovers teares,
Were a rich monument, but too good for her;
Whose misery I glory in: come Sulpitia,
You shall a long with me, good Zabulon
Be not farr off.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I will attend you Madam. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I have serv'd you, from my youth, and ever
You have found me faithfull: that you lives a treasure
I'le locke up here; nor shall it be let forth,
But when you give me warrant.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I rely,
Vpon thy faith; nay, no more protestations,
Too many of them, will call that in question,
Which now I doubt not, she is there.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Alone too
But take it on my life your entertainment,
Appearing as you are, will bee but course
For the displeasure, I shall undergoe;
I am prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Leave me, I'le stand the hazard. Exit Servant.
The silence that's observ'd, her close retirements
No visitance admitted, not the day;
These sable colours, all signes of true sorrow,
Or hers is deeply counterfeit. I'le looke neerer,
Manners give leave— she fits upon the ground;
By heaven she weepes; my picture in her hand too;
She kisses it and weepes againe.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Whos's there?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: There is no starting back now Madam.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Ha, another murderer, I'le not protect thee,
Though I have no more Sonnes.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Your pardon Lady,
Ther's no such foule fact taints me

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: What makes thou here then?
Where are my Servants, do none but my sorrowes
Attend upon me? speake, what brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: A will, to give you comfort.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Thou art but a man.
And 'tis beyond a humane reach to do it
If thou could raise the dead out of their graues.
Bid time run back, make me now what I was,
A happy Mother: gladly I would heare thee,
But that's impossible.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Please you but to read this;
You shall know better there, why I am sent
Then if I should deliver it

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: From whom comes it?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: That will instruct you; I suspect this stranger,
Yet she spake something, that holds such alliance,
With his reports I know not what to thinke on't;
What a frown was ther? she looks me through, & through,
Now reades againe, now pauses, and now smiles;
And yet there's more of anger in't then mirth,
These are strange changes; oh I understand it
She's full of serious thoughts.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You are just you Heavens,
And never do forget to heare their prayers,
That truly pay their vowes, the defer'd vengeance,
For you, and my words sake so long defer'd,
Under which as a mountaine, my heart groanes yet
When 'twas dispair'd of, now is offerd to me;
And if I loose it, I am both wayes guilty,
The womans maske, dissimulation help me;
Come hither freind, I am sure you know the Gentleman,
That sent these charms.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: Charms Lady?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: These charms.
I well may call them so, th'ave won upon me,
More then ere letter did; thou art his freind,
(The confidence he has in thee, confirmes it)
And therefore I'le be open breasted to thee,
To heare of him, though yet, I never saw him,
Was most desir'd of all men; let me blush,
And then I'le say I love him.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: All men see,
In this a womans vertue.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I expected
For the courtesie I did, long since to have seene him,
And though I then forbad it, you men know,
Betweene our harts and tongues, there's a large distance;
But I'le excuse him, may be hitherto,
He has forborne it, in respect my Sonne
Fell by his hand.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: And reason Lady.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: No, he did me a pleasure in't, a riotous fellow,
And with that insolent, not worth the owning▪
I have indeed kept a long solemne sorrow,
For my freinds sake partly; but especially
For his long absence.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: O the Devill!

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Therefore,
Bid him bee speedy; a Preist shall be ready
To tye the holy knot; this kisse I send him,
Deliver that and bring him.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am dumbe:
A good cause I have now, and a good sword,
And something I shall do, I wait upon you. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mannuel. Charino. Arnoldo. Zenocia, borne in a chaire. 2. Doctors. Clodio.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Give her more ayre shee dyes else.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: O thou dread power,
That mad'st this all, and of thy workemanship,
This virgin wife, the Master peice, looke downe on her;
Let her minds virtues, cloth'd in this faire garment,
That worthily deserves, a better name
Then flesh and bloud, now sue, and prevaile for her.
Or if those are denyed, let innocence,
To which, all passages in heaven stand open,
Appeare in her white robe, before thy throne;
And mediate for her: or if this age of sinne,
Be worthy of a miracle, the Sun
In his diurnall progresse never saw,
So sweete a subject to imploy it on.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Wonders are ceas'd Sir, we must worke by meanes,

sp.speaker: Arno.
sp.l: 'Tis true and such reverend Physitians are;
To you— thus low I fall then; so may you ever
Be stil'd the hands of heaven, natures restorers;
Get wealth and honours; and by your successe,
In all your undertakings, propagate
Your great opinion in the world, as now
You use your saving Art; for know good Gentlemen.
Besides the fame, and all that I possess,
For a reward, posterity shall stand
Indebted to you, for (as heaven forbid it)
Should my Zenocia dye, robbing this age,
Of all that's good or gracefull, times succeeding,
The story of her pure life not yet perfect,
Will suffer in the want of her example.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Were all the world to perish with her, wee
Can do no more; then what art and experience
Gives us assurance of, we have us'd all meanes
To finde the cause of her disease, yet cannot;
How should we then, promise the cure?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Away,
I did bely you, when I charg'd you with
The power of doing; yee are meere names only,
And even your best perfection, accidentall;
What ever malady thou art, or spirit,
As some hold, all diseases that afflict us,
As love, already makes me sensible
Of halfe her sufferings, ease her of her part,
And let me stand the butt, of thy fell malice,
And I will sweare th'art mercifull.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Your hand Lady;
What a strange heat is heare? bring some warme water.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: She shall use nothing that is yours; my sorrow,
Provides her of a better bath, my teares,
Shall do that office.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: O my best Arnoldo!
The truest of all lovers! I would live
Were heaven so pleas'd, but to reward your sorrow,
With my true service; but since that's denied me,
May you live long and happy: do not suffer,
(By your affection to me I conjure you)
My sicknesse to infect you; though much love
Makes you too subject to it.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: In this onely
Zenocia Wrongs her servant; can the body
Subsist, the soule departed? 'tis as easy
As I to live without you; I am your husband,
And long have been so, though our adverse fortune,
Banding us, from one hazard to another,
Would never grant me so much happinesse,
As to pay a husbands debt; despite of fortune,
In death I'le follow you, and guarde mine owne;
And there enjoy what heere my fate forbids me.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: So true a sorrow, and so feelingly
Exprest, I never read of.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I am strooke
With wonder to behold it, as with pitty

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: If you that are a stranger, suffer for them,
Being tied no further then humanity
Leades you to soft compassion; thinke great Sir,
What of necessity I must endure,
That am a Father?

div.stage: Hypolita. Zabulon and Sulpitia at the dore.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Waite me there, I hold it
Unfit to have you seene; as I finde cause,
You shall proceed,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are welcome Lady.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Sir, I come to do a charitable office,
How does the patient?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: You may enquire
Of more then one; for two are sick, and deadly,
He languishes in her, her healths, despaird of,
And in hers, his.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: 'Tis a strange spectacle,
With what a patience, they sit unmov'd?
Are they not dead already?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: By her pulse,
She cannot last a day.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Oh by that summons,
I know my time too!

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Looke to the man.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Apply
Your Art, to save the Lady, preserve her,
A towne is your reward.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: I'le treble it,
In ready gold, if you restore Arnoldo;
For in his death I dye too.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: without her,
I am no more.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Are you there Madam? now
You may feast on my miseries; my coldnesse
In answering your affections; or hardnesse,
Give it what name you please, you are reveng'd of;
For now you may perceive, our thred of life
Was spun together, and the poore Arnoldo,
Made only to enjoy the best Zenocia,
And not to serve the use of any other;
And in that she may equall, my Lord Clodio,
Had long since else enjoyed her, nor could I
Have been so blinde, as not to see your great
And many excellencies farr, farr beyond
Or my deservings, or my hopes; we are now
Going our latest journey, and together,
Our onely comfort we desire, pray give it
Your charitie to our ashes, such wee must be,
And not to curse our memoryes.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: I am much mov'd.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I am wholly overcome, all love to women,
Farewell for ever, ere you dye, your pardon;
And yours Sir; had she many yeares to live,
Perhaps I might looke on her, as a Brother,
But as a lover never; and since all
Your sad misfortunes, had originall
From the barbarous custome practiz'd in my Countrey,
Heaven witnesse, for your sake I here release it;
So to your memory, chast Wives and Virgins
Shall ever pay their vowes. I give her to you;
And wish, she were so now, as when my lust
Forc'd you; to quite the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: It is in vaine,
To strive with destiny, here my dotage ends,
Looke up Zenocia, health in me speakes to you;
She giues him to you, that by divers wayes,
So long has kept him from you: and repent not,
That you were once my servant, for which health
In recompence of what I made you suffer,
The hundred thousand Crownes, the Citie owes me,
Shall be your dower.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis a magnificent guift,
Had it beene timely given.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: It is beleeve it; Sulpitia?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Madam

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Quicke, undoe the charme;
Aske not a reason why; let it suffice,
It is my will.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Which I obey and gladly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is to be married sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: So she sayes sir,
And does desire your presence. They are borne off in chaires

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And tell her I'le come.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Pray carry them to their rest; for though already,
They do appeare as dead, let my life pay for't,
If they recover not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What you have warranted,
Assure your selfe, will be expected from you;
Looke to them carefully; and till the tryall,

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Which shall not be above foure howers.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Let me
Intreate your companies: there is something
Of waight, invites me hence.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: weell waite upon you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You understand what my directions are,
And what they guide you to; the faithfull promise,
You have made me all.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We do and will performe it.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: The Governour will not faile to be here presently
Retire a while, till you shall finde occasion,
And bring me word, when they arrive.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Wee shall Madam.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Onely stay you to entertaine;

sp.speaker: 1. Ser
sp.l: I am ready

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I wonder at the bold, and practis'd malice,
Men ever haue a foote, against our honours,
That nothing we can do, never so verteous,
No shape put on so pious, no not thinke
What a good is, be that good ne're so noble,
Never so Laden with admir'd example,
But still we end in lust; our aimes our actions,
Nay, even our charities, with lust are branded;
Why should this stranger else, this wretched stranger,
Whose life I sav'd at what deare price, stick here yet?
Why should he hope, he was not here an hower,
And certainly in that time, I may sweare it
I gave him no loose looke, I had no reason;
Unlesse my teares were flames, my curses courtships;
The killing of my Sonne, a kindnesse to me,
Why should he send to me, or with what safety
(Examining the ruine he had wrought me)
Though at that time, my pious pitty found him,
And my word fixt; I am troubled, strongly troubled.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Gentlemen are come,

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Then bid 'em welcome— I must retire. Exit.
You are welcome home Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I thank you freind, I would speak with your Lady.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I'le let her understand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: It shall befit you,
How do I looke Sir, in this handsome trim? Exit. Servant.
Me thinks I am woundrous brave.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: You are very decent.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: These by themselves, without more helps of nature,
Would set a woman hard; I know 'em all,
And where their first aimes light; I'le lay my head on't,
I'le take her eye, as soone as she lookes on me,
And if I come to speake once, woe be to her,
I have her in a nooze, she cannot scape me;
I have their severall lasts.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: You are throughly studied,
But tel me Sir, being unacquainted with her,
As you confesse you are—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: That's not an howers worke,
I'le make a nun forget her beades in two houres.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: She being set in yeares next, none of those lusters
Appearing in her eye, that warme the fancy;
Nor nothing in her face, but handsome ruines.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I love old storyes; those live beleev'd, Authentique,
When 20. of your moderne faces, are cald in,
For new opinion paintings, and corruptions,
Give me an old confirm'd face; besides she sav'd me,
She sav'd my life, have I not cause to love her?
Shee's rich and of a constant state, a faire one
Have I not cause to wooe her? I have tryed sufficient,
All your young Phillies, I thinke this back has tryed 'em,
And smarted for it too: they run away with me,
Take bitt betweene the teeth, and play the Divels;
A staied pace now becomes my yeares; a sure one,
Where I may sit and cracke no girthes.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: How miserable,
If my Mother should confirme, what I suspect now,
Beyond all humane cure were my condition?
Then I shall wish, this body had been so too,
Here comes the Lady Sir.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Excellent Lady,
To shew I am a creature, bound to your service,
And onely yours—

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Keepe at that distance Sir;
For if you stirr—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am obedient,
She has found already, I am for her turne;
With what a greedy hawkes eye she beholds me?
Marke how she musters all my parts.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: A goodly Gentleman,
Of a more manly set, I never look'd on.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Marke, marke her eye still; marke but the carriage of 'em

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: How happy am I now; since my Sonne fell,
He fell not, by a base unnoble hand?
As that still troubled me; how farr more happy
Shall my revenge be, since the sacrifice,
I offer to his grave, shall be both worthy,
A Sonnes untimely losse, and a Mothers sorrow?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Sir, I am made beleeve it; she is mine owne,
I told you what a spell I carried with me,
All this time does she spend, in contemplation,
Of that unmatch'd delight: I shall be thankfull to yee;
And if you please to know my house, to use it;
To take it for your owne.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Who waites without there?

div.stage: Enter. Guard. and Servants. they seize upon Rut. & bind him.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How now? what meanes this, Lady?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Binde him fast.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Are these the bride-lases you prepare for me?
The colours that you give?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Fy gentle Lady,
This is not noble dealing.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Be you satisfied,
It seemes you are a stranger to this meaning,
You shall not be so long

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Do you call this wooing— Is there no end of womens persecutions?
Must I needs foole into mine owne destruction?
Have I not had faire warnings, and enough too?
Still pick the Divells teeth? you are not mad Lady;
Do I come fairely, and like a Gentleman,
To offer you that honour?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd Sir
You come besotted, to your owne destruction:
I sent not for you; what honour can ye add to me,
That brake that staffe of honour, my age lean'd on?
That robd me of that right, made me a Mother?
Heare me thou wretched man, heare me with terrour,
And let thine owne bold folly shake thy soule,
Heare me pronounce thy death, that now hangs o're thee,
Thou desperate foole; who bad thee seeke this ruine?
What mad unmanly fate, made thee discover
Thy cursed face to me againe? wast not enough
To have the faire protection of my house,
When misery and justice, cloose persued thee?
When thine owne bloudy sword, cryed out against thee,
Hatcht in the life of him? yet I forgave thee;
My hospitable word, even when I saw
The goodliest branch of all my blood, lopt from me,
Did I not Seale still to thee?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am gon.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: And when thou went'st to Impe thy miserie,
Did I not give thee meanes? but harke ungratefull,
Was it not thus? to hide thy face and fly me?
To keep thy name for ever from my memory?
Thy cursed blood and kindred; did I not sweare then
If ever, (in this wretched life thou hast left me,
Short and unfortunate,) I saw thee againe,
Or came but to the knowledge, where thou wanderdst,
To call my vowe back, and pursue with vengance
With all the miseryes a Mother suffers?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I was borne to be hang'd, there's no auoyding it.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: And dar'st thou with this impudence appeare here?
Walke like the winding sheete my Sonne was put in,
Stand with those wounds?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am happy now againe;
Happy the hower I fell, to finde a Mother,
So pious good, and excellent in sorrowes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Governours come in.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O let him enter.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have fool'd my selfe a faire thred of all my fortunes,
This strikes me most; not that I feare to perish,
But that this unmanerly boldnesse, has brought me to it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Are these fit preparations for a wedding Lady?
I came prepar'd a guest.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O give me justice;
As ever you will leave a vertuous name,
Do justice, justice, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: You need not aske it,
I am bound to it.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Iustice upon this man
That kild my Sonne.

sp.speaker: Gove.
sp.l: Do you confesse the act?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Rutillio?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: 'Tis the same.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: How fell he thus?
Here will be sorrow for the good Arnoldo.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Take heed Sir what you say.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have weigh'd it well,
I am the man, nor is it life I start at;
Onely I am unhappy I am poore,
Doore in expence of lives, there I am wretched,
That I have not two lives lent me for his sacrifice;
One for her Sonne, another for her sorrowes.
Excellent Lady, now rejoyce againe,
For though I cannot thinke, y'are pleas'd in blood,
Nor with that greedy thirst pursue your vengeance;
The tendernesse, even in those teares denies that;
Yet let the world beleeve, you lov'd Duarte;
The unmatcht courtesies you have done my miseries,
Without this forfeite to the law, would charge me
To tender you this life, and proud t'would please you.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Shall I have justice?

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'le aske it for ye,
I'le follow it my selfe, against my selfe.
Sir, 'Tis most fit I dye; dispatch it quickly,
The monstrous burthen of that griefe she labours with
Will kill her else, then blood on blood lyes on me;
Had I a thousand liues, I'd give e'm all,
Before I would draw one teare more from that vertue.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Be not too cruell Sir, and yet his bold sword—
But his life cannot restore that he's a man too—
Of a faire promise, but alas my Sonnes dead;
If I have justice, must it kill him?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: If I have not, it kills me, strong and goodly!
Why should he perish too?

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: It lies in your power,
You onely may accuse him, or may quitt him.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Be there no other witnesses?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Not any.
And if I save him, will not the world proclaime,
I have forgot a Sonne, to save a murderer?
And yet he lookes not like one, he lookes manly.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Pitty so brave a Gentleman should perish.
She cannot be so hard, so cruell harted.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Will you pronounce? yet stay a little Sir.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Rid your selfe Lady, of this misery;
And let me go, I do but breed more tempests,
With which you are already, to much shaken.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Do now, pronounce; I will not heare.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: You shall not,
Yet turne and see good Madam.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Do not wonder.
'Tis he, restor'd againe, thanke the good Doctor,
Pray do not stand amaz'd, it is Duarte;
Is well, is safe againe.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O my sweete Sonne.
I will not presse my wonder now with questions—
Sir, I am sorry for that cruelty,
I urg'd against you.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Madam it was but justice.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: 'Tis true, the Doctor heald this body againe,
But this man heald my soule, made my minde perfect,
The good sharp lessons his sword read to me, sav'd me;
For which, if you lov'd me deare Mother,
Honour and love this man.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You sent this letter,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: My boldnesse makes me blush now.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I'le wipe of that,
And with this kisse, I take you for my husband,
Your woings done Sir; I beleeve you love me,
And that's the wealth I looke for now.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You have it.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: You have ended my desire to all my wishes.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Now 'tis a wedding againe. And if Hypollita,
Make good, what with the hazard of her life,
She undertooke, the evening will sett cleare.
sp.stage: Enter. Hypollita. leading Leopold. Arnoldo. Zenocia. in either hand. Zabulon. Sulpitia.
sp.l: After a stormy day.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Here comes the Lady.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: With faire Zenocia,
Health with life againe,
Restor'd unto her.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: The guift of her goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Let us embrace, I am of your order too,
And though I once despair'd of women, now,
I finde they rellish much of Scorpions,
For both have stings, and both can hurt, and cure too;
But what have been your fortunes?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Wee'le defer
Our story, and at time more fit, relate it.
Now all that reverence vertue, and in that
Zenocias constancy, and perfect love,
Or for her sake Arnoldo, joyne with us
In th' honour of this Lady.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: She deserves it.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Hypollitas life, shall make that good hereafter,
Nor will I alone, better my selfe but others:
For these whose wants perhaps, have made their actions
Not altogether innocent, shall from me
Be so supplied; that need should not compell them,
To any course of life, but what the law
Shall give allowance to.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Sulp. Your Ladishipps creatures.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Be so and no more, you man-huckster.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: And worthy Leopold, you that with such fervour,
So long have sought me, and in that deserv'd me,
Shall now finde full reward, for all your travelles,
Which you have made more deare, by patient sufferance.
And though my violent dotage did transport me,
Beyond those bounds, my modesty should have kept in,
Though my desires were loose, from unchast art,
Heaven knows I am free.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: The thought of that's dead to me;
I gladly take your offer.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Do so Sir,
A peice of crackt gold, ever will weigh downe
Siluer that's whole.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You shall be all my guests,
I must not be denyed.

sp.speaker: Arno.
sp.l: Come my Zenocia.
Our barke at length has found a quiet harbour;
And the unspotted progresse of our loves
Ends not alone in safety but reward,
To instruct others, by our faire example;
That though good purposes, are long withstood,
The hand of Heaven still guides such as are good.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: SO free this worke is, Gentlemen, from offence,
That we are confident, it needes no defence
From us, or from the Poets— wee dare looke.
On any man, that brings his Table-booke
To write downe, what againe he may repeate
At some greate Table, to deserve his meate.
Let such come sweld with malice, to apply
What it mirth here, there for an injurie.
Nor Lord, nor Lady we have tax'd; nor State,
Nor any private person, their poore hate
Will be starv'd heere, for envy shall not finde,
One touch that may be wrested to her minde.
And yet despaire not Gentlemen, The play
Is quicke and witty; so the Poets say,
And we believe them; the plott neate, and new,
Fashiond like those, that are approv'd by you.
Onely 'twill crave attention, in the most;
Because one point unmark'd, the whole is lost
Heare first then, and judge after, and be free,
And as our cause is, let our censure be.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: WHy there should be an Epilogue to a Play.
I know no cause, the old and usuall way,
For which they were made, was to entreat the grace
Of such as were spectators in this place,
And time, 'tis to no purpose; for I know
What you resolve already to bestow,
Will not be alterd, what so ere I say,
In the behalfe of us, and of the Play:
Onely to quitt our doubts, if you thinke fit,
You may, or cry it up; or silence it.

div.head: Another Prologue for the Custome of the Countrey. For my Sonne Clarke.
div.l: WEe wish, if it were possible, you knew
What we would give for this nights looke, if new?
It being our ambition to delight
Our kinde spectators with what's good, and right.
Yet so farre know, and credite me, 'twas made
By such, as were held work-men in their Trade,
At a time too, when they as I divine,
Were truly merrie, and dranke lusty wine.
The nectar of the Muses; Some are here
I dare presume, to whom it did appeare.
A well-drawne piece, which gave a lawfull birth
To passionate Scoenes mixt with no vulgar mirth.
But unto such to whom 'tis knowne by fame
From others, perhaps only by the name.
I am a suitor, that they would prepare
Sound palats, and then judge their bill of fare.
It were injustice to decry this now
For being like'd before, you may allow
(Your candor safe) what's taught in the olde schooles,
All such as liv'd before you, were not fooles.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: I Spake much in the Prologue for the Play,
To its desert I hope, yet you might say
Should I change now from that, which then was meant,
Or in a syllable grow lesse confident.
I were weake-hearted. I am still the same
In my opinion, and forbeare to frame
Qualification, or excuse: If you
Concur with me, and hold my judgement true.
Shew it with any signe, and from this place,
Or send me off exploded, or with grace.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
